instructors.bio: David Evans is a Professor of Computer Science at the University of Virginia where he teaches computer science and leads research in computer security. He is the author of an introductory computer science textbook and has won Virginia's highest award for university faculty. He has PhD, SM, and SB degrees from MIT.
instructors.name: David Evans

course.name: Applied Cryptography
course.faq:
Is there a fee to take the course?
Nope, no fees. All of our classes are offered free of charge.

Can you enroll in more than one class?
Yes! Keep in mind CS101 is intended for students with no previous programming background, CS212, 253 and 262 are courses are oriented towards students with some programming experience (the equivalent of CS101), while CS373 and CS387 assumes students have prior programming experience.

When do classes start?
April 16, 2012.

When do I have to be online to watch the lectures?
The lectures are posted each week for you to view at your convenience.

How is the class formatted?
Both classes are broken into 6 week-long units and seventh week that wraps up the course and has a final exam. Each unit contains multiple lecture segments with interactive quizzes built in. There will be one homework assignment which will include programming problems each week. There will be approximately 50 minutes of lecture videos.

Will there be closed captioning?
Yes, the videos will have captions in English. We're also working to support other languages in future.

What will I get for completing the classes?
Students who complete a course will also receive a certificate signed by the instructors.
course.syllabus:
Description: Cryptography is about “secret writing”. In this class, we will introduce the mathematical foundations of cryptography and build programs to perform encryption. We will see how to use cryptography to solve important problem such as how to authenticate users, secure websites, and do computation without exposing up your data. We will also look at the things that can go wrong when cryptography is misused or implemented badly.

WEEK 1:

Symmetric Encryption
Sending messages when two people share a secret


WEEK 2:

Authentication
Using symmetric encryption to manage passwords securely


WEEK 3:

Asymmetric Encryption
Public-key cryptosystems


WEEK 4:

Public-key Protocols
Secure commerce, certificates


WEEK 5:

Digital Cash
How to make money from numbers alone


WEEK 6:

Secure Computation
Computing without exposing data


WEEK 7:

Wrap-up
Problems cryptography can and cannot solve
course.prereqs: This course assumes previous programming experience, comparable to what is covered by the Udacity CS101 course, as well as some understanding of probability and theory of computation and algorithm analysis.
course.description: Cryptography is present in everyday life, from paying with a credit card to using the telephone. Learn all about making and breaking puzzles in computing.

media.name: cs387_unit1_05_q_Correctness-and-Security
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:03,000
So now that we have the key, we have three main things:

2
00:00:03,000 --> 00:00:07,000
we have a message in the spaces of all messages,

3
00:00:07,000 --> 00:00:10,000
we have a ciphertext in the spaces of all ciphertexts,

4
00:00:10,000 --> 00:00:15,000
and we have a key in the space of all possible keys.

5
00:00:15,000 --> 00:00:22,000
And we want our encryption function--we'll take a message and a key--

6
00:00:22,000 --> 00:00:25,000
and map that to a ciphertext, and our decryption function

7
00:00:25,000 --> 00:00:31,000
will take a ciphertext and a key and map that to a message.

8
00:00:31,000 --> 00:00:36,000
And to be correct, we need to obtain the same message after decryption,

9
00:00:36,000 --> 00:00:42,000
we need to know--for all messages and keys--we have the property--

10
00:00:42,000 --> 00:00:47,000
the decrypting--using that key, and I'm going to use the notation

11
00:00:47,000 --> 00:00:49,000
where I put the key as a subscript to the decryption function,

12
00:00:49,000 --> 00:00:53,000
instead of as an input, but that means the same thing as saying

13
00:00:53,000 --> 00:00:55,000
there are two inputs to decryption, one is the key,

14
00:00:55,000 --> 00:01:00,000
one is to input ciphertext, and the input ciphertext is the result of encrypting

15
00:01:00,000 --> 00:01:04,000
using that same key--that message--and we want to know for correctness

16
00:01:04,000 --> 00:01:11,000
that that value must always be the message that was input to the encryption function.

17
00:01:11,000 --> 00:01:13,000
Correctness, of course, is not enough.

18
00:01:13,000 --> 00:01:15,000
We also want security,

19
00:01:15,000 --> 00:01:17,000
and our security property, in an ideal sense,

20
00:01:17,000 --> 00:01:21,000
would be that the ciphertext reveals nothing at all about the key or the message.

21
00:01:21,000 --> 00:01:24,000
We're going to formalize this a little later, this unit. 

22
00:01:24,000 --> 00:01:27,000
For now, let's think about that property informally,  

23
00:01:27,000 --> 00:01:29,000
and what I'm going to ask you is a quiz,

24
00:01:29,000 --> 00:01:33,000
to see whether given functions satisfy our correctness property.

25
00:01:33,000 --> 00:01:37,000
So now it's time for a quiz to see that you understand the correctness property

26
00:01:37,000 --> 00:01:39,000
for a symmetric cipher.

27
00:01:39,000 --> 00:01:44,000
Which of the functions below satisfy the correctness property

28
00:01:44,000 --> 00:01:46,000
for a symmetric cipher?

29
00:01:46,000 --> 00:01:49,000
And we'll assume both the message space--the set of all possible messages--

30
00:01:49,000 --> 00:01:53,000
and the key space--the set of all possible keys--are the natural numbers,

31
00:01:53,000 --> 00:01:54,000
so the whole numbers starting from 1.

32
00:01:54,000 --> 00:01:57,000
So, each choice is a pair of functions--the encryption function,

33
00:01:57,000 --> 00:01:59,000
and the decryption function.

34
00:01:59,000 --> 00:02:03,000
For the first choice, the encryption function adds the message and the key.

35
00:02:03,000 --> 00:02:08,000
For this decryption function, we subtract from the ciphertext, the key.

36
00:02:08,000 --> 00:02:12,000
For the second choice, the encryption function is the identity.

37
00:02:12,000 --> 00:02:15,000
The decryption function is the identity on the ciphertext.

38
00:02:15,000 --> 00:02:18,000
For the third choice, I am using the modulo operator,  

39
00:02:18,000 --> 00:02:22,000
x modulo y is the remainder you get when you divide x by y,

40
00:02:22,000 --> 00:02:25,000
and modulo is a very useful operation in cryptography.

41
00:02:25,000 --> 00:02:28,000
We'll see that quite a bit later on this unit, as well as in later units.

media.name: cs387_unit1_00_q_Introduction
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:03,000
Welcome to Applied Cryptography.

2
00:00:03,000 --> 00:00:05,000
Cryptography is a branch of mathematics

3
00:00:05,000 --> 00:00:06,000
and computer science--that's a lot of fun--it's about

4
00:00:06,000 --> 00:00:09,000
using secrets to solve problems.

5
00:00:09,000 --> 00:00:10,000
In this class we're going to learn about

6
00:00:10,000 --> 00:00:12,000
some of the foundations of cryptography

7
00:00:12,000 --> 00:00:15,000
and we're also going to learn to use cryptography

8
00:00:15,000 --> 00:00:16,000
to solve problems in computing,

9
00:00:16,000 --> 00:00:17,000
like how to send messages securely,

10
00:00:17,000 --> 00:00:20,000
how to manage accounts on websites,

11
00:00:20,000 --> 00:00:22,000
and how to do things like perform computation

12
00:00:22,000 --> 00:00:24,000
where you can keep your data secret

13
00:00:24,000 --> 00:00:25,000
and still get the result of a function

14
00:00:25,000 --> 00:00:27,000
that depends on your data and some other data.

15
00:00:27,000 --> 00:00:30,000
The name cryptography has two parts:

16
00:00:30,000 --> 00:00:34,000
crypto comes from the Greek root for secret--to hide--

17
00:00:34,000 --> 00:00:37,000
and cryptography's all about using secrets.

18
00:00:37,000 --> 00:00:40,000
The second part comes from the root meaning writing--

19
00:00:40,000 --> 00:00:44,000
this is the same graphy that appears in telegraphy or photography.

20
00:00:44,000 --> 00:00:47,000
What we do in this course, and what we do in cryptography

21
00:00:47,000 --> 00:00:50,000
involves a lot more than just secret writing.

22
00:00:50,000 --> 00:00:51,000
It's really everything to do with secrets.

23
00:00:51,000 --> 00:00:56,000
So a better name for the course would be cryptology.

24
00:00:56,000 --> 00:00:58,000
Cryptography is used so frequently in practice, though, 

25
00:00:58,000 --> 00:01:00,000
that it makes more sense to use the name cryptography,

26
00:01:00,000 --> 00:01:04,000
even though our concern is with the much larger goal

27
00:01:04,000 --> 00:01:07,000
of understanding how to use secrets in general.

28
00:01:07,000 --> 00:01:10,000
And cryptology is the science of secrets

29
00:01:10,000 --> 00:01:12,000
which is really what this course is all about.

30
00:01:12,000 --> 00:01:15,000
So that's enough to answer the first quiz,

31
00:01:15,000 --> 00:01:18,000
and the first quiz will check

32
00:01:18,000 --> 00:01:21,000
 that you understand the definition of cryptology.

33
00:01:21,000 --> 00:01:24,000
So the question is, which of these involve cryptology?

34
00:01:24,000 --> 00:01:25,000
Check all of the answers that do.

35
00:01:25,000 --> 00:01:28,000
Opening a door--and I mean a traditional door,

36
00:01:28,000 --> 00:01:30,000
using a traditional key.

37
00:01:30,000 --> 00:01:31,000
Playing a game of poker.

38
00:01:31,000 --> 00:01:35,000
Logging into your account at Udacity,

39
00:01:35,000 --> 00:01:37,000
or doing a search using google.com,

40
00:01:37,000 --> 00:01:40,000
and I should be a little more specific for this last one,

41
00:01:40,000 --> 00:01:43,000
this assumes you're doing the search today,

42
00:01:43,000 --> 00:01:46,000
and you're already logged in to one of your Google accounts.

media.name: cs387_unit1_04_q_Keys-and-Kerchoffs-Principle
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:02,000
We'll talk about that a little more later,

2
00:00:02,000 --> 00:00:07,000
before I go on, I want to mention one very important principle in cryptography,

3
00:00:07,000 --> 00:00:10,000
which is known as Kerckhoff's Principle,

4
00:00:10,000 --> 00:00:14,000
and it goes back to a book that Kerckhoff wrote back in 1883,

5
00:00:14,000 --> 00:00:20,000
and the way Kerckhoff stated it was this--this was in a book he wrote in 1883

6
00:00:20,000 --> 00:00:29,000
about military cryptography [speaking French],

7
00:00:29,000 --> 00:00:34,000
and I apologize for my French, but this loosely translates as,

8
00:00:34,000 --> 00:00:38,000
"The cipher must not depend on secrecy of the mechanism.

9
00:00:38,000 --> 00:00:42,000
It must not matter if it falls in the hands of the enemy."

10
00:00:42,000 --> 00:00:45,000
So, the reason for that--and it's important--

11
00:00:45,000 --> 00:00:48,000
what he's focusing on is the mechanism here.

12
00:00:48,000 --> 00:00:51,000
So, if you think about these two functions we need--

13
00:00:51,000 --> 00:00:52,000
we need encryption and decryption.

14
00:00:52,000 --> 00:00:55,000
Coming up with new functions--or new mechanisms--

15
00:00:55,000 --> 00:00:58,000
in Kerckhoff's day these were mostly mechanical devices

16
00:00:58,000 --> 00:01:01,000
 that you needed as part of the encryption process--

17
00:01:01,000 --> 00:01:03,000
well, that's a lot of work.

18
00:01:03,000 --> 00:01:07,000
You don't want to have to keep inventing new encryption and decryption functions,

19
00:01:07,000 --> 00:01:10,000
and deciding they're secure and distributing them.

20
00:01:10,000 --> 00:01:12,000
What you want is some way that,

21
00:01:12,000 --> 00:01:15,000
 even if your encryption and decryption functions are known,

22
00:01:15,000 --> 00:01:17,000
your cipher can still be secure,

23
00:01:17,000 --> 00:01:20,000
and the way to achieve that is to use a key.

24
00:01:20,000 --> 00:01:23,000
So instead of just having the message as input to the encryption function,

25
00:01:23,000 --> 00:01:26,000
the other input to the encryption is a key,

26
00:01:26,000 --> 00:01:30,000
and if it's a symmetric cryptosystem, that same key

27
00:01:30,000 --> 00:01:34,000
is the key that is needed in the decryption function as well.

28
00:01:34,000 --> 00:01:36,000
If the security relies only on keeping the key secret,

29
00:01:36,000 --> 00:01:40,000
well, then, we can make our encryption and decryption functions public,

30
00:01:40,000 --> 00:01:42,000
we can analyze them, we can put a lot of work

31
00:01:42,000 --> 00:01:45,000
into developing good encryption and decryption functions,

32
00:01:45,000 --> 00:01:49,000
and then the security depends only on keeping the key secret.

33
00:01:49,000 --> 00:01:51,000
If we think our key has been exposed, 

34
00:01:51,000 --> 00:01:53,000
well, then we just need to come up with a new key,

35
00:01:53,000 --> 00:01:55,000
but we can keep using the same functions.

36
00:01:55,000 --> 00:01:59,000
If the function turns out to have a weakness in it,

37
00:01:59,000 --> 00:02:00,000
well, that's a much more serious problem.

38
00:02:00,000 --> 00:02:03,000
Then we need to develop a new encryption function

39
00:02:03,000 --> 00:02:06,000
and argue that that function is secure.

40
00:02:06,000 --> 00:02:08,000
So, this quiz is to check that you understand

41
00:02:08,000 --> 00:02:11,000
Kerckhoff's Principle and understand the terms that we've defined.

42
00:02:11,000 --> 00:02:17,000
So the question is: which parts of a cryptosystem must be kept secret?

43
00:02:17,000 --> 00:02:22,000
The choices are: Alice, the algorithm used for encryption,

44
00:02:22,000 --> 00:02:27,000
the algorithm used for decryption, the keys, and the ciphertext.

45
00:02:27,000 --> 00:02:30,000
Check all the parts that must be kept secret.

nuggets.name: Do Not Implement Your Own Crypto

media.name: cs387_unit1_02_q_Do-Not-Implement-Your-Own-Crypto
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:03,000
We'll get into both the mathematics and the practice

2
00:00:03,000 --> 00:00:05,000
 of implementing systems using cryptography,

3
00:00:05,000 --> 00:00:08,000
but there's one thing I want to really emphasize,

4
00:00:08,000 --> 00:00:10,000
and make sure that you understand.

5
00:00:10,000 --> 00:00:13,000
Implementing your own cryptography is very challenging,

6
00:00:13,000 --> 00:00:16,000
it's something that is very easy to do incorrectly.

7
00:00:16,000 --> 00:00:18,000
One example of that to keep in mind--

8
00:00:18,000 --> 00:00:20,000
and this is an important thing--

9
00:00:20,000 --> 00:00:23,000
so we often think about programs as black boxes

10
00:00:23,000 --> 00:00:25,000
with inputs and outputs,

11
00:00:25,000 --> 00:00:29,000
and our encryption functions will usually take a key in a message 

12
00:00:29,000 --> 00:00:32,000
and produce some ciphertext, 

13
00:00:32,000 --> 00:00:35,000
and the implementations we'll show in this class

14
00:00:35,000 --> 00:00:36,000
will be functionally correct,

15
00:00:36,000 --> 00:00:39,000
they'll produce the correct outputs.

16
00:00:39,000 --> 00:00:40,000
They won't be secure,

17
00:00:40,000 --> 00:00:42,000
and the reason they won't be secure is

18
00:00:42,000 --> 00:00:45,000
things aren't really black boxes when we use them.

19
00:00:45,000 --> 00:00:48,000
There's lots of other things that someone

20
00:00:48,000 --> 00:00:49,000
 could observe about this.

21
00:00:49,000 --> 00:00:52,000
They could observe how long it takes.

22
00:00:52,000 --> 00:00:54,000
And when you can observe properties

23
00:00:54,000 --> 00:00:57,000
of a function--other than their functional behavior--

24
00:00:57,000 --> 00:00:58,000
other than just their inputs and outputs--

25
00:00:58,000 --> 00:01:00,000
that's called a side channel.

26
00:01:00,000 --> 00:01:03,000
An example of a side channel is timing.

27
00:01:03,000 --> 00:01:06,000
So, the time it takes to run this function could vary,

28
00:01:06,000 --> 00:01:09,000
it could depend on the message or the key.

29
00:01:09,000 --> 00:01:11,000
Most of the code that we're going to write in this class

30
00:01:11,000 --> 00:01:12,000
will have that property.

31
00:01:12,000 --> 00:01:15,000
We're not going to be adding complexity

32
00:01:15,000 --> 00:01:17,000
 to our code to worry about things like side channels,

33
00:01:17,000 --> 00:01:20,000
but in terms of implementing things correctly,

34
00:01:20,000 --> 00:01:21,000
that's really important,

35
00:01:21,000 --> 00:01:24,000
and there are lots of ways that code could have side channels.

36
00:01:24,000 --> 00:01:26,000
It could affect what's in the cache of the processor,

37
00:01:26,000 --> 00:01:28,000
and that could be visible in some way,

38
00:01:28,000 --> 00:01:30,000
it could actually affect how much power

39
00:01:30,000 --> 00:01:32,000
your processor uses,

40
00:01:32,000 --> 00:01:34,000
and people have shown ways to break smart cards

41
00:01:34,000 --> 00:01:38,000
by measuring the power consumption as they do encryption

42
00:01:38,000 --> 00:01:39,000
and that gives you some insight into what the key is.

43
00:01:39,000 --> 00:01:42,000
So, this is just an example of the kinds of things

44
00:01:42,000 --> 00:01:46,000
that it's very hard to get right in implementing cryptography.

45
00:01:46,000 --> 00:01:49,000
These are things that, if you were building cryptography

46
00:01:49,000 --> 00:01:52,000
for any important use, you'd have to worry about.

47
00:01:52,000 --> 00:01:54,000
These are things that we are not going to worry about

48
00:01:54,000 --> 00:01:57,000
in most of the code that we write in this class

49
00:01:57,000 --> 00:02:02,000
so you shouldn't view these implementations as secure implementations.

50
00:02:02,000 --> 00:02:04,000
The only reason to implement your own crypto

51
00:02:04,000 --> 00:02:06,000
is for fun and learning.

52
00:02:06,000 --> 00:02:09,000
And that's what we hope you'll get from this class by doing it,

53
00:02:09,000 --> 00:02:11,000
but if you actually want to use cryptography

54
00:02:11,000 --> 00:02:13,000
 to protect anything important, well--

55
00:02:13,000 --> 00:02:15,000
you should use a library implementation

56
00:02:15,000 --> 00:02:16,000
that's been carefully vetted,

57
00:02:16,000 --> 00:02:18,000
that's been written in a way to worry about

58
00:02:18,000 --> 00:02:22,000
these kinds of issues like timing side channels,

59
00:02:22,000 --> 00:02:23,000
and that other people have looked at

60
00:02:23,000 --> 00:02:25,000
carefully enough to have some higher level of confidence

61
00:02:25,000 --> 00:02:28,000
that it's correct and secure.

62
00:02:28,000 --> 00:02:32,000
So I want to make sure everyone was paying careful attention

63
00:02:32,000 --> 00:02:33,000
to that last point,

64
00:02:33,000 --> 00:02:35,000
and we'll have a quiz:

65
00:02:35,000 --> 00:02:37,000
Should you use any code from this course

66
00:02:37,000 --> 00:02:39,000
to protect nuclear launch codes?

67
00:02:39,000 --> 00:02:42,000
The answers are no--check the correct answer.

media.name: cs387_unit1_00_s_Introduction
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:04,000
The answer is all of these involve cryptography,

2
00:00:04,000 --> 00:00:07,000
and the reason for that is they all involve secrets.

3
00:00:07,000 --> 00:00:08,000
Let's go through each in turn.

4
00:00:08,000 --> 00:00:12,000
So the first is opening a door with a mechanical key.

5
00:00:12,000 --> 00:00:14,000
What's the secret there?

6
00:00:14,000 --> 00:00:16,000
Well, let's look at a key.

7
00:00:16,000 --> 00:00:19,000
So, the secret is actually the shape of the key.

8
00:00:19,000 --> 00:00:21,000
Now that I've shown you this key,

9
00:00:21,000 --> 00:00:23,000
there's no secret any more.

10
00:00:23,000 --> 00:00:26,000
If you can look at the ridges on the key,

11
00:00:26,000 --> 00:00:28,000
well, you know the secret.

12
00:00:28,000 --> 00:00:30,000
You can make a copy of the key

13
00:00:30,000 --> 00:00:33,000
and open whatever door this opens--

14
00:00:33,000 --> 00:00:35,000
hopefully it's not something very important--

15
00:00:35,000 --> 00:00:38,000
since I've just shown the key in a public video,

16
00:00:38,000 --> 00:00:40,000
and it's actually possible to do this

17
00:00:40,000 --> 00:00:42,000
from a fairly large distance.

18
00:00:42,000 --> 00:00:46,000
There was a group of students at University of California, San Diego,

19
00:00:46,000 --> 00:00:48,000
that showed that from taking a picture 

20
00:00:48,000 --> 00:00:50,000
several hundred feet away you could learn

21
00:00:50,000 --> 00:00:52,000
enough about a key to create a replica

22
00:00:52,000 --> 00:00:54,000
that would open the same door.

23
00:00:54,000 --> 00:00:55,000
Playing poker certainly involves secrets.

24
00:00:55,000 --> 00:00:57,000
It wouldn't be much of a game if everyone

25
00:00:57,000 --> 00:00:59,000
could see everyone else's cards.

26
00:00:59,000 --> 00:01:03,000
Logging into your Udacity account involves

27
00:01:03,000 --> 00:01:05,000
entering an email and password,

28
00:01:05,000 --> 00:01:07,000
and I'm not going to actually type my password now,

29
00:01:07,000 --> 00:01:11,000
because--one of the things I hope you'll start to understand from this class is--

30
00:01:11,000 --> 00:01:13,000
even if you don't see it because of the stars here,

31
00:01:13,000 --> 00:01:16,000
the fact that you can hear the audio of my keyboard

32
00:01:16,000 --> 00:01:19,000
 would give you a pretty big clue about what my password is

33
00:01:19,000 --> 00:01:20,000
and the number of characters.

34
00:01:20,000 --> 00:01:22,000
And--unlike the key that I showed you--

35
00:01:22,000 --> 00:01:24,000
this protects something really important

36
00:01:24,000 --> 00:01:26,000
so I'm not going to expose my password.

37
00:01:26,000 --> 00:01:29,000
We will talk, in one of the future units,

38
00:01:29,000 --> 00:01:32,000
about how to manage passwords correctly.

39
00:01:32,000 --> 00:01:34,000
This involves a lot of encryption--your password is a secret--

40
00:01:34,000 --> 00:01:36,000
but you also want to manage passwords--  

41
00:01:36,000 --> 00:01:41,000
and check them--in a way that doesn't require storing those secrets.

42
00:01:41,000 --> 00:01:44,000
You don't want to store passwords in a way that could expose them easily,

43
00:01:44,000 --> 00:01:46,000
and we'll talk about that more in unit 2.

44
00:01:46,000 --> 00:01:49,000
The final option--doing a search using google.com--

45
00:01:49,000 --> 00:01:51,000
is an interesting one.

46
00:01:51,000 --> 00:01:53,000
This actually changed about a year ago--

47
00:01:53,000 --> 00:01:55,000
whether or not that involves encryption--

48
00:01:55,000 --> 00:01:59,000
and, if you try it today, you'll note when you enter google.com

49
00:01:59,000 --> 00:02:01,000
what happens is, you actually get redirected

50
00:02:01,000 --> 00:02:06,000
to https://google.com and--you can see the lock in the browser--

51
00:02:06,000 --> 00:02:09,000
this means it's using a protocol called TLS

52
00:02:09,000 --> 00:02:12,000
 to encrypt all the traffic between you and Google.

53
00:02:12,000 --> 00:02:15,000
So--both the keywords that you're typing are not exposed on the internet--

54
00:02:15,000 --> 00:02:17,000
as well as the search results,

55
00:02:17,000 --> 00:02:20,000
and we'll talk more about that in a later unit in the class

56
00:02:20,000 --> 00:02:23,000
that involves both asymmetric and symmetric encryption.

57
00:02:23,000 --> 00:02:26,000
There's lots of interesting things about the protocol

58
00:02:26,000 --> 00:02:29,000
to protect web traffic, that we'll talk about later in the class.

59
00:02:29,000 --> 00:02:31,000
So the key point is that secrets are all around us,

60
00:02:31,000 --> 00:02:33,000
that they're very useful for solving problems,

61
00:02:33,000 --> 00:02:36,000
you're using cryptology all the time, every day.

media.name: cs387_unit1_03_l_Symmetric-Cryptosystems
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:06,000
So the first main topic we'll introduce is symmetric cryptosystems.

2
00:00:06,000 --> 00:00:10,000
Symmetric means both encryption and decryption are done with the same key.

3
00:00:10,000 --> 00:00:14,000
I want to introduce some terminology that we'll use throughout the course.

4
00:00:14,000 --> 00:00:16,000
So we can think of encryption as a function,

5
00:00:16,000 --> 00:00:21,000
and it takes as input a plain text--this is the unencrypted message--

6
00:00:21,000 --> 00:00:24,000
it outputs a ciphertext, and then our goal is to be able

7
00:00:24,000 --> 00:00:28,000
to send that ciphertext over an insecure channel.

8
00:00:28,000 --> 00:00:32,000
This could be a wireless network, this could be the internet,

9
00:00:32,000 --> 00:00:34,000
this could be a courier carrying your message,

10
00:00:34,000 --> 00:00:37,000
any channel where we can't trust the channel to be secure.

11
00:00:37,000 --> 00:00:42,000
We hope what comes out of the channel is the same ciphertext we put into it. 

12
00:00:42,000 --> 00:00:46,000
Then that goes into a decryption function, and what comes out 

13
00:00:46,000 --> 00:00:48,000
is the message that we sent it.

14
00:00:48,000 --> 00:00:52,000
Our cast of characters--we often talk about Alice sending the message,

15
00:00:52,000 --> 00:00:54,000
Bob receiving it.

16
00:00:54,000 --> 00:00:58,000
We also have malicious characters who might be listening in on this channel.

17
00:00:58,000 --> 00:01:01,000
One of those is called Eve--for eavesdropper--and she has really big ears

18
00:01:01,000 --> 00:01:05,000
and can hear the messages sent between Alice and Bob, 

19
00:01:05,000 --> 00:01:08,000
but she only hears what's sent over the insecure channel,

20
00:01:08,000 --> 00:01:12,000
she doesn't have access to the plain text--that's the input to the encryption function--

21
00:01:12,000 --> 00:01:15,000
or the plain text that comes out of the decryption function at the other end.

22
00:01:15,000 --> 00:01:19,000
But she can hear the ciphertext that's sent over the insecure channel.

23
00:01:19,000 --> 00:01:22,000
To think about this a little more precisely,

24
00:01:22,000 --> 00:01:27,000
the plain text is some message, and it's selected from a set of messages.

25
00:01:27,000 --> 00:01:29,000
So, M is the set of all possible messages,

26
00:01:29,000 --> 00:01:34,000
and M could be finite--for a given length, M is finite--

27
00:01:34,000 --> 00:01:37,000
and we'll often be thinking about fixed-length messages,

28
00:01:37,000 --> 00:01:42,000
so there's a finite set of them, and M is some message selected from that set.

29
00:01:42,000 --> 00:01:48,000
The ciphertext is C--selected from the set of all possible ciphertexts,

30
00:01:48,000 --> 00:01:51,000
and the encryption and decryption functions are functions.

31
00:01:51,000 --> 00:01:53,000
The encryption function--as shown here--

32
00:01:53,000 --> 00:01:59,000
is a function that goes from an element of M to an element of C.

33
00:01:59,000 --> 00:02:04,000
The decryption function goes from an element of C--a ciphertext--to an element of M.

34
00:02:04,000 --> 00:02:11,000
In order for Bob to receive the same message as the one Alice encrypted,

35
00:02:11,000 --> 00:02:15,000
we need this property--that the D function is an inverse of the M function.

36
00:02:15,000 --> 00:02:18,000
So we need it to be the case for all messages.

37
00:02:18,000 --> 00:02:21,000
The result of decryption the encryption of that message is the same as the message we started with.

media.name: cs387_unit1_04_s_Keys-and-Kerchoffs-Principle
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:03,000
The answer is: just the keys.

2
00:00:03,000 --> 00:00:04,000
This is the point of Kerckhoff's Principle,

3
00:00:04,000 --> 00:00:08,000
that we don't need to keep the encryption algorithm or the decryption algorithm secret,

4
00:00:08,000 --> 00:00:12,000
we want to make those public so they are carefully tested and understood,

5
00:00:12,000 --> 00:00:14,000
and analyzed by many people.

6
00:00:14,000 --> 00:00:17,000
We wanted only to keep this key secret.

7
00:00:17,000 --> 00:00:19,000
The point of the encryption system is to allow us

8
00:00:19,000 --> 00:00:22,000
to send the ciphertext over an insecure channel,

9
00:00:22,000 --> 00:00:24,000
so that's no longer going to be secret,

10
00:00:24,000 --> 00:00:27,000
and Alice is just a silly answer.

nuggets.name: Do Not Implement Your Own Crypto Solution

media.name: cs387_unit1_02_s_Do-Not-Implement-Your-Own-Crypto
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:02,000
So I hope everyone got this quiz correctly.

2
00:00:02,000 --> 00:00:05,000
If you didn't, you'll be hearing from our lawyers soon.

nuggets.name: Otp Is A Perfect Cipher Pt 2

media.name: cs387_unit1_14_s_OTP-is-a-Perfect-Cipher-pt-2
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:02,000
The answer is this one. 

2
00:00:02,000 --> 00:00:08,000
It's the probability that the message is M* divided by the number of keys.

3
00:00:08,000 --> 00:00:11,000
To see why let's think about our probability space.

4
00:00:11,000 --> 00:00:14,000
We have all the possible messages being ordered.

5
00:00:14,000 --> 00:00:20,000
We have message 0, message 1, all the possible messages.

6
00:00:20,000 --> 00:00:24,000
There is some message that we've selected that's message M8.

7
00:00:24,000 --> 00:00:27,000
We don't want to assume that the messages are uniformly distributed.

8
00:00:27,000 --> 00:00:31,000
The probability that the message is M* is not necessarily 

9
00:00:31,000 --> 00:00:34,000
1 divided by the number of messages.

10
00:00:34,000 --> 00:00:38,000
If the messages were uniformly distributed, then this answer would also be correct.

11
00:00:38,000 --> 00:00:40,000
But they're not. We don't want to assume that.

12
00:00:40,000 --> 00:00:44,000
Maybe the attacker has some prior knowledge about the distribution of the messages.

13
00:00:44,000 --> 00:00:46,000
That's normally the case.

14
00:00:46,000 --> 00:00:49,000
Even if we don't know anything about the particular messages,

15
00:00:49,000 --> 00:00:52,000
maybe we know it's a message in English.

16
00:00:52,000 --> 00:00:56,000
Most random strings of text are not messages in English.

17
00:00:56,000 --> 00:01:00,000
The other dimension in our probability space is the choice of the key.

18
00:01:00,000 --> 00:01:03,000
There are K possible keys.

19
00:01:03,000 --> 00:01:07,000
What we want to know is what is the intersection of these two events.

20
00:01:07,000 --> 00:01:10,000
The M* even is this line in our probability space.

21
00:01:10,000 --> 00:01:15,000
Each one of these keys maps exactly one message to C.

22
00:01:15,000 --> 00:01:19,000
We saw that before, that there is one key that maps each message to C.

23
00:01:19,000 --> 00:01:23,000
We can think of that as being a diagonal line through our probability space.

24
00:01:23,000 --> 00:01:28,000
This is the line where the encryption of Ki and Mi is equal to C.

25
00:01:28,000 --> 00:01:33,000
Depending on what C is, it might not be a diagonal line.

26
00:01:33,000 --> 00:01:35,000
But we can think of it that way, that there's one key 

27
00:01:35,000 --> 00:01:38,000
that maps each message to each cipher text.

28
00:01:38,000 --> 00:01:42,000
That means there's exactly one point here where those two intersect.

29
00:01:42,000 --> 00:01:46,000
If the distributions were normal, that would indeed by the correct answer.

30
00:01:46,000 --> 00:01:50,000
It's one point and our space is the size of M times the size of K.

31
00:01:50,000 --> 00:01:52,000
But the distribution isn't normal.

32
00:01:52,000 --> 00:01:55,000
We don't want to make any assumption about the distribution of M.

33
00:01:55,000 --> 00:01:58,000
For the keys we do want to assume that the distribution is normal,

34
00:01:58,000 --> 00:02:02,000
that each key is equally likely. The keys are chosen perfectly at random.

35
00:02:02,000 --> 00:02:05,000
We have the probability of picking M*, 

36
00:02:05,000 --> 00:02:09,000
and we're multiplying that by the probability of picking this intersecting key.

37
00:02:09,000 --> 00:02:11,000
We'll call that K*.

38
00:02:11,000 --> 00:02:16,000
But because the keys are uniformly distributed, we know that this probability is 1/K--

39
00:02:16,000 --> 00:02:18,000
1 over the size of K.

40
00:02:18,000 --> 00:02:20,000
We don't know that about the messages.

41
00:02:20,000 --> 00:02:23,000
We leave that probability as it is.

42
00:02:23,000 --> 00:02:29,000
That's why this is the answer to the probability that the message M* intersected 

43
00:02:29,000 --> 00:02:32,000
with the encryption of the message is C.

44
00:02:32,000 --> 00:02:35,000
Now let's go back to our definition.

media.name: cs387_unit1_24_l_Modern-Symmetric-Ciphers
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:05,000
We won't talk in much detail about modern symmetric ciphers in this course.

2
00:00:05,000 --> 00:00:07,000
There are a couple reasons for this.

3
00:00:07,000 --> 00:00:10,000
One is that I want to get on to uses of ciphers, 

4
00:00:10,000 --> 00:00:13,000
which I think is more important and more interesting for most people.

5
00:00:13,000 --> 00:00:16,000
Very few people today need to implement a cipher.

6
00:00:16,000 --> 00:00:21,000
You really should use library implementations of ciphers in any serious application.

7
00:00:21,000 --> 00:00:25,000
It's certainly useful to understand more about what's going on beneath the scenes.

8
00:00:25,000 --> 00:00:28,000
But even few people should be designing new ciphers.

9
00:00:28,000 --> 00:00:31,000
You would have to have very unique requirements to think 

10
00:00:31,000 --> 00:00:34,000
that you're better off designing a new cipher yourself than using

11
00:00:34,000 --> 00:00:38,000
a standard well-accepted carefully analyzed cipher.

12
00:00:38,000 --> 00:00:41,000
Most of the time we've used ciphers as black boxes

13
00:00:41,000 --> 00:00:47,000
that are taking in messages and keys and outputing ciphertext

14
00:00:47,000 --> 00:00:50,000
and assuming that they have the properties that we need.

15
00:00:50,000 --> 00:00:54,000
Certainly we've proven that no cipher really does.

16
00:00:54,000 --> 00:00:57,000
We've shown that the only way for a cipher to be perfect

17
00:00:57,000 --> 00:01:02,000
is if the key space is at least as big as the message space.

18
00:01:02,000 --> 00:01:05,000
That's impractical for any useful use.

19
00:01:05,000 --> 00:01:08,000
We can group modern ciphers into two types.

20
00:01:08,000 --> 00:01:12,000
There are stream ciphers and block ciphers.

21
00:01:12,000 --> 00:01:17,000
The different is that with a stream cipher we've got a stream of data,

22
00:01:17,000 --> 00:01:21,000
and our cipher can encrypt small chunks at a time.

23
00:01:21,000 --> 00:01:25,000
You can think of the data streaming through the cipher encrypting

24
00:01:25,000 --> 00:01:29,000
encrypting usually at the level of one byte at a time,

25
00:01:29,000 --> 00:01:32,000
whereas with the block cipher we think of our data in larger chunks,

26
00:01:32,000 --> 00:01:35,000
and the cipher encrypts a block at a time.

27
00:01:35,000 --> 00:01:44,000
Usually a block size is at least 64 bits and can be longer up to 128 or 256 bits.

28
00:01:44,000 --> 00:01:46,000
These are sort of really the same thing.

29
00:01:46,000 --> 00:01:49,000
The only difference is changing the block size.

30
00:01:49,000 --> 00:01:52,000
If the block size is small enough, it would become a stream cipher.

31
00:01:52,000 --> 00:01:57,000
If the block size is large enough, we can think of it as a block cipher.

32
00:01:57,000 --> 00:02:02,000
But there are enough differences in the way you build ciphers 

33
00:02:02,000 --> 00:02:04,000
that different ciphers are designed for each purpose.

34
00:02:04,000 --> 00:02:09,000
The most important block cipher today is known as AES,

35
00:02:09,000 --> 00:02:12,000
and this stands for the Advanced Encryption Standard.

36
00:02:12,000 --> 00:02:17,000
AES is a block cipher. It works on blocks of 128 bits.

37
00:02:17,000 --> 00:02:23,000
AES is the result of the competition that was run by the United States 

38
00:02:23,000 --> 00:02:29,000
National Institute of Standards in Technology, more commonly known as NIST.

39
00:02:29,000 --> 00:02:36,000
This competition was started in 1997 to find a cipher to replace DES, 

40
00:02:36,000 --> 00:02:41,000
which was the Data Encryption Standard, which had been a standard for the previous 30 years.

41
00:02:41,000 --> 00:02:46,000
That contest ran from 1997. They had a very open process.

42
00:02:46,000 --> 00:02:52,000
This is very unlike the process that was used to select DES as the previous recommended cipher.

43
00:02:52,000 --> 00:02:56,000
This lead to 15 submissions for round 1.

44
00:02:56,000 --> 00:02:58,000
Some of these were actually completely broken.

45
00:02:58,000 --> 00:03:01,000
Others were rejected for other reasons.

46
00:03:01,000 --> 00:03:05,000
This was narrowed down to five finalists, none of which were seriously broken,

47
00:03:05,000 --> 00:03:08,000
and one winner, which was selected.

48
00:03:08,000 --> 00:03:15,000
The main criteria for selecting the winner of AES were the security of the ciphers,

49
00:03:15,000 --> 00:03:17,000
and this is really the hardest thing to measure.

50
00:03:17,000 --> 00:03:20,000
We've seen that other than the one-time pad

51
00:03:20,000 --> 00:03:24,000
provable security is not achievable for most ciphers

52
00:03:24,000 --> 00:03:28,000
and not achievable for any cipher that was a candidate for AES.

53
00:03:28,000 --> 00:03:32,000
The way this was measured was trying to estimate the security.

54
00:03:32,000 --> 00:03:36,000
The main metric for measuring security was looking at 

55
00:03:36,000 --> 00:03:41,000
the actual number of rounds in the cipher and dividing it by the minimum number of rounds

56
00:03:41,000 --> 00:03:45,000
that were breakable in some sense.

57
00:03:45,000 --> 00:03:49,000
Breakable here is very much the academic of breakable.

58
00:03:49,000 --> 00:03:53,000
You didn't need to be able to extract a message or a key.

59
00:03:53,000 --> 00:03:57,000
Anything that showed you could reduce the search space even a little bit would be enough

60
00:03:57,000 --> 00:04:00,000
to show that it was breakable for that number of rounds.

61
00:04:00,000 --> 00:04:04,000
The other properties were easier to compare and measure, which were speed--

62
00:04:04,000 --> 00:04:09,000
implementing it both in hardware and in software--and simplicity.

63
00:04:09,000 --> 00:04:12,000
Simplicity is usually against security.

64
00:04:12,000 --> 00:04:15,000
To have higher security we want more confusion.

65
00:04:15,000 --> 00:04:19,000
We want to do more transformations to the data. That goes against simplicity.

66
00:04:19,000 --> 00:04:26,000
Simplicity aids the analysis to make it more clear whether the cipher is secure or not.

67
00:04:26,000 --> 00:04:32,000
The winner of the AES competition was a cipher known as Rijndael, 

68
00:04:32,000 --> 00:04:35,000
which was developed by two Belgian cryptographers.

69
00:04:35,000 --> 00:04:38,000
The good thing about it winning AES is now we don't have to figure out how 

70
00:04:38,000 --> 00:04:43,000
to pronounce it correctly in Belgian. It's now called AES.

71
00:04:43,000 --> 00:04:47,000
The best known current break against AES is very theoretical, 

72
00:04:47,000 --> 00:04:56,000
so with 128-bit keys, that would be a brute-force attack that tries every possible key.

73
00:04:56,000 --> 00:05:00,000
It would require on average 2^127 attempts.

74
00:05:00,000 --> 00:05:04,000
You're expected within half the 128-bit keys.

75
00:05:04,000 --> 00:05:12,000
You've got 2^128 total keys. You expect to find a break after testing half of them

76
00:05:12,000 --> 00:05:16,000
So they expect it costs a brute-force attack 2^127.

77
00:05:16,000 --> 00:05:20,000
The best known attack removes less than 1 bit of security.

78
00:05:20,000 --> 00:05:23,000
That's the best known today.

79
00:05:23,000 --> 00:05:28,000
And 126 bits of security is well beyond what's practical to imagine implementing

80
00:05:28,000 --> 00:05:31,000
even with a huge amount of computing resources.

nuggets.name: Otp Is A Perfect Cipher Pt 1

media.name: cs387_unit1_05_s_Correctness-and-Security
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:04,000
The answer is: the first two of these do satisfy the correctness property,

2
00:00:04,000 --> 00:00:05,000
the third one does not.

3
00:00:05,000 --> 00:00:10,000
And to understand why--well, let's remember what the correctness property is.

4
00:00:10,000 --> 00:00:16,000
That's that for any message, and any key, we have the property that

5
00:00:16,000 --> 00:00:18,000
when we encrypt the message with that key, 

6
00:00:18,000 --> 00:00:19,000
and decrypt it with the same key,

7
00:00:19,000 --> 00:00:21,000
we get the message back.

8
00:00:21,000 --> 00:00:26,000
And this is what we need for our encryption to be decryptable.

9
00:00:26,000 --> 00:00:27,000
We need these functions to be inverses.

10
00:00:27,000 --> 00:00:32,000
So, for the first choice, the encryption function is M + K,

11
00:00:32,000 --> 00:00:36,000
the decryption function takes that input--which is now called C--

12
00:00:36,000 --> 00:00:40,000
and subtracts K from it using the properties of arithmetic

13
00:00:40,000 --> 00:00:43,000
while this is indeed equal to M.

14
00:00:43,000 --> 00:00:47,000
For the second choice, the encryption function is the identity,

15
00:00:47,000 --> 00:00:48,000
that gives us M back. 

16
00:00:48,000 --> 00:00:51,000
Certainly this does not provide the security properties that we need,

17
00:00:51,000 --> 00:00:54,000
we haven't hidden anything about the message.

18
00:00:54,000 --> 00:00:57,000
And then the decryption function is also the identity.

19
00:00:57,000 --> 00:00:59,000
Takes in M, gives us M back.

20
00:00:59,000 --> 00:01:04,000
So this satisfies correctness, certainly does not satisfy security.

21
00:01:04,000 --> 00:01:09,000
The third property doesn't satisfy the correctness property.

22
00:01:09,000 --> 00:01:16,000
And the easy way to see that is to observe that the output of this

23
00:01:16,000 --> 00:01:19,000
is a smaller set than the number of messages.

24
00:01:19,000 --> 00:01:23,000
So there--for some choices of message and key, this maps to the same value,

25
00:01:23,000 --> 00:01:30,000
and an example of that would be, if we choose K = 2, if M = 4,

26
00:01:30,000 --> 00:01:34,000
then the encryption of that message is equal to zero,

27
00:01:34,000 --> 00:01:40,000
because the remainder of dividing 4 by 2 is zero.

28
00:01:40,000 --> 00:01:43,000
But if we also choose to message 6, well then, 

29
00:01:43,000 --> 00:01:47,000
the encryption with that same key of 6 is zero.

30
00:01:47,000 --> 00:01:50,000
Since two messages mapped to the same ciphertext,

31
00:01:50,000 --> 00:01:53,000
there's no way they could decrypt correctly,

32
00:01:53,000 --> 00:01:55,000
they can't both decrypt to different values,

33
00:01:55,000 --> 00:01:58,000
because decryption is just a function, it takes that input, 

34
00:01:58,000 --> 00:02:01,000
it's going to produce the same output in both cases,

35
00:02:01,000 --> 00:02:03,000
in this case it's going to produce zero, it's not going to produce the message we need.

36
00:02:03,000 --> 00:02:06,000
So this is neither secure nor correct.

37
00:02:06,000 --> 00:02:10,000
But once it's not correct we know it's not useful.

38
00:02:10,000 --> 00:02:14,000
The first one, as it is, is not secure.

39
00:02:14,000 --> 00:02:17,000
But it's actually pretty close to being secure.

40
00:02:17,000 --> 00:02:20,000
And if we combine the first one with a modulo operator,

41
00:02:20,000 --> 00:02:24,000
and we never reuse keys, we'll end up with something that's perfectly secure.

42
00:02:24,000 --> 00:02:26,000
And that's what I'm going to talk about next.

43
00:02:26,000 --> 00:02:29,000
I'll introduce the first cipher that we'll talk about, 

44
00:02:29,000 --> 00:02:32,000
and it's actually a cipher that is perfectly secure.

media.name: cs387_unit1_06_q_XOR-Function
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:02,000
So I'm going to introduce a cipher called the One-Time Pad,

2
00:00:02,000 --> 00:00:05,000
and this is actually a perfect cipher,

3
00:00:05,000 --> 00:00:08,000
and we'll define more precisely what that means,

4
00:00:08,000 --> 00:00:13,000
but it's a cipher that reveals no information at all about the key or the message,

5
00:00:13,000 --> 00:00:15,000
and it's actually the only one.

6
00:00:15,000 --> 00:00:19,000
And--you might be wondering--well, if we're starting right at the beginning of the class

7
00:00:19,000 --> 00:00:20,000
with a perfect cipher, what's there left to do?

8
00:00:20,000 --> 00:00:23,000
It's perfect, but it's very impractical.

9
00:00:23,000 --> 00:00:28,000
And the reason it's very impractical is because it requires huge keys.

10
00:00:28,000 --> 00:00:32,000
So to understand the One-Time Pad, the first thing we need to understand

11
00:00:32,000 --> 00:00:36,000
 is the XOR function--which is a name for the exclusive or--

12
00:00:36,000 --> 00:00:42,000
and it's often written as a plus with a circle around it.

13
00:00:42,000 --> 00:00:45,000
The truth table for XOR is this:

14
00:00:45,000 --> 00:00:53,000
the value of A XOR B is true if one of A or B--but only one of them--is true.

15
00:00:53,000 --> 00:00:55,000
So that's why we end up with this truth table.

16
00:00:55,000 --> 00:01:02,000
XOR has lots of useful properties that make it the favorite function of every cryptographer,

17
00:01:02,000 --> 00:01:05,000
and I'll see if you can figure out one of these on your own.

18
00:01:05,000 --> 00:01:08,000
So the question is: for any values X and Y,

19
00:01:08,000 --> 00:01:12,000
what is the value of x XOR y XOR x?

20
00:01:12,000 --> 00:01:17,000
So here are your choices: 0, x, y, or it depends on x.

nuggets.name: Do Not Implement Your Own Crypto
Otp Is A Perfect Cipher Pt 1

media.name: cs387_unit1_13_q_OTP-is-a-Perfect-Cipher-pt-1
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:04,000
Our goal is to show that a one-time pad is a perfect cipher,

2
00:00:04,000 --> 00:00:07,000
and now that we have the definition of a perfect cipher,

3
00:00:07,000 --> 00:00:09,000
we should be able to argue that formally.

4
00:00:09,000 --> 00:00:11,000
This was our definition. 

5
00:00:11,000 --> 00:00:13,000
Since our definition uses the conditional probability, 

6
00:00:13,000 --> 00:00:16,000
we should also remember the definition of conditional probability,

7
00:00:16,000 --> 00:00:22,000
which is the probability of some event A conditioned on event B happening

8
00:00:22,000 --> 00:00:27,000
is equal to the probability of A intersect B divided by the probability of B.

9
00:00:27,000 --> 00:00:30,000
To show that the one-time pad is a perfect cipher,

10
00:00:30,000 --> 00:00:38,000
we just need to calculate this where A will be this event and B will be this event.

11
00:00:38,000 --> 00:00:40,000
We need to know the probability of B, 

12
00:00:40,000 --> 00:00:44,000
which is the probability that some message with some key encrypts to C.

13
00:00:44,000 --> 00:00:49,000
Let's compute that first. Then we'll need to compute the probability of A intersect B.

14
00:00:49,000 --> 00:00:51,000
We'll have a little quiz.

15
00:00:51,000 --> 00:00:56,000
Given any message and any cipher text C, and we're using a one-time pad,

16
00:00:56,000 --> 00:01:03,000
how many different keys are there that encrypt that message to that cipher text?

media.name: cs387_unit1_06_s_XOR-Function
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:05,000
So the answer is always y, and this is why this is such a useful function

2
00:00:05,000 --> 00:00:10,000
in cryptography--if we XOR in the value of x twice, they cancel out.

3
00:00:10,000 --> 00:00:16,000
So the general property for any value x--x XOR x-- is equal to 0.

4
00:00:16,000 --> 00:00:17,000
We can see that from the truth table.

5
00:00:17,000 --> 00:00:25,000
The value of x could either be 0--and 0 XOR 0 is 0--or 1, and the value of 1 XOR 1 is 0,

6
00:00:25,000 --> 00:00:29,000
and that means that x XOR x is always 0.

7
00:00:29,000 --> 00:00:39,000
XOR is also associative and commutative, so that means if we have x XOR y XOR x 

8
00:00:39,000 --> 00:00:46,000
that's equivalent to x XOR x XOR y which is also equivalent to y.

9
00:00:46,000 --> 00:00:53,000
And I've written this using x's and y's--if we change the names of our letters to M and C

10
00:00:53,000 --> 00:00:56,000
it becomes really clear why this is useful in cryptography.

11
00:00:56,000 --> 00:01:04,000
If we call x the key, then we have the key XOR the message--that's going to be the ciphertext--

12
00:01:04,000 --> 00:01:09,000
and then the ciphertext XOR the key again gives us back the message.

13
00:01:09,000 --> 00:01:13,000
And what I've described is exactly the One-Time Pad.

14
00:01:13,000 --> 00:01:19,000
The key aspect is--why it's called One-Time--is that we can only use the key once.

15
00:01:19,000 --> 00:01:22,000
So if we do this one bit at a time, we need a new key for each bit.

16
00:01:22,000 --> 00:01:27,000
If we think of doing it for a longer message, well then we need a key long enough

17
00:01:27,000 --> 00:01:30,000
that we're XORing each bit with one bit of the key.

media.name: cs387_unit1_11_s_Probability-Review-pt-3
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:04,000
We can compute this using the formula for conditional probability.

2
00:00:04,000 --> 00:00:09,000
In this case what A is is the probability the coin toss is valid.

3
00:00:09,000 --> 00:00:18,000
A is valid, and we know that the probability of A is equal to 0.99998.

4
00:00:18,000 --> 00:00:21,000
What B is is the probability that it's heads.

5
00:00:21,000 --> 00:00:29,000
So the probability of B is the probability of H, which is 0.49999.

6
00:00:29,000 --> 00:00:32,000
Now we just have to plug these into the formula.

7
00:00:32,000 --> 00:00:36,000
But what we need to use the formula is the probability of A intersect B.

8
00:00:36,000 --> 00:00:42,000
And what A is the probability of A intersect B. What A is is valid.

9
00:00:42,000 --> 00:00:46,000
Instead of heads and tails, what B is is heads.

10
00:00:46,000 --> 00:00:52,000
If we intersect heads and tails with heads, we get tails.

11
00:00:52,000 --> 00:00:57,000
We know the probability of tails is 0.49999.

12
00:00:57,000 --> 00:01:04,000
That means using the formula we have the probability of tails, which is 0.49999,

13
00:01:04,000 --> 00:01:07,000
which is the probability of A intersect B.

14
00:01:07,000 --> 00:01:12,000
We're dividing that by the probability of A,

15
00:01:12,000 --> 00:01:18,000
which is a valid event which is 0.99998.

16
00:01:18,000 --> 00:01:20,000
We get 0.5.

17
00:01:20,000 --> 00:01:23,000
I should note that this is not the case for real coin tosses.

18
00:01:23,000 --> 00:01:28,000
There is no physical coin ever manufactured that has exactly 

19
00:01:28,000 --> 00:01:30,000
chances of landing on both sides.

20
00:01:30,000 --> 00:01:34,000
In fact, with real coin tosses, at least with American currency,

21
00:01:34,000 --> 00:01:39,000
there is a much higher percentage--much higher meaning close to 51%

22
00:01:39,000 --> 00:01:43,000
rather than 50%--that the coin lands on the same side that it started on.

23
00:01:43,000 --> 00:01:46,000
When we talk about mathematical coin tosses,

24
00:01:46,000 --> 00:01:48,000
we're going to assume that there is no edge case 

25
00:01:48,000 --> 00:01:50,000
and that it's equally likely 

26
00:01:50,000 --> 00:01:53,000
that we have a uniform distribution and there are only 2 outcomes.

27
00:01:53,000 --> 00:01:56,000
When we talk about mathematical coin tosses,

28
00:01:56,000 --> 00:01:58,000
we're going to assume that we have a uniform distribution,

29
00:01:58,000 --> 00:02:01,000
and there are only two outcomes.

media.name: cs387_unit1_07_q_One-Time-Pad
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:02,000
So let's define that a little more precisely.

2
00:00:02,000 --> 00:00:04,000
So we're going to find our set of messages--

3
00:00:04,000 --> 00:00:10,000
is strings of 0s and 1s--so we'll use bits and some fixed length.

4
00:00:10,000 --> 00:00:14,000
So n is number that gives us the maximum length of a message. 

5
00:00:14,000 --> 00:00:18,000
Our message is selected from all binary strings of length n.

6
00:00:18,000 --> 00:00:23,000
Our key is also selected from the set of all binary strings of length n.

7
00:00:23,000 --> 00:00:26,000
And then to do encryption--our encryption function--

8
00:00:26,000 --> 00:00:29,000
we're going to think of the message as being this sequence of bits

9
00:00:29,000 --> 00:00:32,000
and the key is also a sequence of bits.

10
00:00:32,000 --> 00:00:35,000
The result of our encryption is the ciphertext,

11
00:00:35,000 --> 00:00:37,000
which is a sequence of bits.

12
00:00:37,000 --> 00:00:40,000
So, length n, where the value of each ciphertext bit

13
00:00:40,000 --> 00:00:43,000
is equal to the XOR of the corresponding message bit

14
00:00:43,000 --> 00:00:45,000
and the corresponding key bit.

15
00:00:45,000 --> 00:00:46,000
So let's try an example.

16
00:00:46,000 --> 00:00:50,000
And for this example, I'm going to give you the ciphertext

17
00:00:50,000 --> 00:00:51,000
 and the key and the message.

18
00:00:51,000 --> 00:00:54,000
So suppose our message is the string 'CS,' 

19
00:00:54,000 --> 00:00:57,000
but our message space is in bits.

20
00:00:57,000 --> 00:01:00,000
Well, the first thing we need to do is to convert those strings to bits

21
00:01:00,000 --> 00:01:03,000
and we can do that in Python by using ord,

22
00:01:03,000 --> 00:01:06,000
that takes a one character string and turns it into 

23
00:01:06,000 --> 00:01:07,000
a decimal number.

24
00:01:07,000 --> 00:01:11,000
And then we need to convert that decimal number into bits.

25
00:01:11,000 --> 00:01:13,000
Into a binary number.

26
00:01:13,000 --> 00:01:16,000
And we need to do this for each character in the string.

27
00:01:16,000 --> 00:01:19,000
We're going to convert it to a character, convert that to bits,

28
00:01:19,000 --> 00:01:22,000
and I'll show you the code for doing that,

29
00:01:22,000 --> 00:01:25,000
we'll leave the more interesting code for you to write.

30
00:01:25,000 --> 00:01:27,000
Here we're converting to bits.

31
00:01:27,000 --> 00:01:32,000
This is a fairly straightforward, but not the shortest way to do this.

32
00:01:32,000 --> 00:01:36,000
We're going to make an array of bits as our result for any decimal number 

33
00:01:36,000 --> 00:01:42,000
if it's divisible by 2, we want to have a 0 at the beginning of a result.

34
00:01:42,000 --> 00:01:44,000
If it's not divisible by 2, that's going to be a 1.

35
00:01:44,000 --> 00:01:48,000
And then we divide the number by 2 as we go forward.

36
00:01:48,000 --> 00:01:49,000
So that's going to fill up all the places.

37
00:01:49,000 --> 00:01:53,000
We want our bits to be particular lengths,

38
00:01:53,000 --> 00:01:54,000
so we have a padding,

39
00:01:54,000 --> 00:01:57,000
and for all the characters, we'll use 7 bits.

40
00:01:57,000 --> 00:02:00,000
So we're going to pad the result with leading zeros

41
00:02:00,000 --> 00:02:02,000
until we get to that size.

42
00:02:02,000 --> 00:02:06,000
We can see this--so if we do ord we see that

43
00:02:06,000 --> 00:02:09,000
the number corresponding to the letter C is 67.

44
00:02:09,000 --> 00:02:13,000
If we convert that to bits--and we'll use 7 as our padding--

45
00:02:13,000 --> 00:02:16,000
that gives us enough for 128 different values

46
00:02:16,000 --> 00:02:19,000
which is enough for the ASCII character values

47
00:02:19,000 --> 00:02:20,000
that we get back from ord.

48
00:02:20,000 --> 00:02:23,000
We can see those bits as a list,

49
00:02:23,000 --> 00:02:26,000
and we can see that a little more easily as a string

50
00:02:26,000 --> 00:02:31,000
using the display bits procedure that just turned that into a string.

51
00:02:31,000 --> 00:02:33,000
So now we want to convert more than one character.

52
00:02:33,000 --> 00:02:36,000
To do that, we have a string to bits procedure

53
00:02:36,000 --> 00:02:39,000
that goes through all the characters in the string,

54
00:02:39,000 --> 00:02:42,000
converting each one to bits using convert to bits,

55
00:02:42,000 --> 00:02:44,000
and concatenating those all together to the result.

56
00:02:44,000 --> 00:02:47,000
So now we can do string to bits.

57
00:02:47,000 --> 00:02:50,000
For our two-letter string, and now we get 14 bits as a result.

58
00:02:50,000 --> 00:02:54,000
So if that's our message, then the value of M is what we got there.

59
00:02:54,000 --> 00:02:56,000
So this is our message.

60
00:02:56,000 --> 00:02:59,000
There are 14 bits, n is 14.

61
00:02:59,000 --> 00:03:01,000
That means--to encrypt this using a One-Time Pad, 

62
00:03:01,000 --> 00:03:05,000
we need a key that also has 14 bits.

63
00:03:05,000 --> 00:03:07,000
So let's pick our key,

64
00:03:07,000 --> 00:03:10,000
and--we're just going to make up a random key now. 

65
00:03:10,000 --> 00:03:14,000
Actually finding random values is very important in cryptography,

66
00:03:14,000 --> 00:03:16,000
and we'll talk about that in a later unit, 

67
00:03:16,000 --> 00:03:18,000
but for now let's just make one up.

68
00:03:18,000 --> 00:03:19,000
So suppose this is our key.

69
00:03:19,000 --> 00:03:21,000
Then the ciphertext is just the result of XOR 

70
00:03:21,000 --> 00:03:25,000
in each message bit with the corresponding key bit. 

71
00:03:25,000 --> 00:03:26,000
So that's our ciphertext.

72
00:03:26,000 --> 00:03:29,000
So the question is, as an interceptor,

73
00:03:29,000 --> 00:03:31,000
you saw just this ciphertext, you don't know anything

74
00:03:31,000 --> 00:03:34,000
 about the message or the key, and you're going to guess 

75
00:03:34,000 --> 00:03:36,000
possible key values to try to figure out what the message is.

76
00:03:36,000 --> 00:03:38,000
And what key value would you guess

77
00:03:38,000 --> 00:03:41,000
that would mislead you to think that the message 

78
00:03:41,000 --> 00:03:44,000
was actually BS instead of CS?

media.name: cs387_unit1_12_q_Perfect-Cipher
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:03,000
Now we're ready to define what a perfect cipher is

2
00:00:03,000 --> 00:00:06,000
and to see why the one-time pad satisfies this property.

3
00:00:06,000 --> 00:00:09,000
The notion that we want a perfect cipher to mean

4
00:00:09,000 --> 00:00:13,000
is that if an attacker intercepts a message they receive the cipher text

5
00:00:13,000 --> 00:00:18,000
that provides them with no additional information at all about what the plain text was.

6
00:00:18,000 --> 00:00:21,000
We have a message. It's being encrypted with a key.

7
00:00:21,000 --> 00:00:25,000
The attacker is intercepting that cipher text as it's sent over the insecure channel.

8
00:00:25,000 --> 00:00:29,000
What we want to know is that an attacker who sees just the cipher text 

9
00:00:29,000 --> 00:00:31,000
learns nothing about the message.

10
00:00:31,000 --> 00:00:34,000
If you followed the definition of conditional probability,

11
00:00:34,000 --> 00:00:36,000
you should be able to decide how to define that formally.

12
00:00:36,000 --> 00:00:38,000
We'll make that a quiz.

13
00:00:38,000 --> 00:00:42,000
The question is which of these is the property that we want in order for a cipher to be perfect?

14
00:00:42,000 --> 00:00:48,000
That is, to have this property that the cipher text reveals no information about the plain text.

15
00:00:48,000 --> 00:00:50,000
I'm going to introduce some notation.

16
00:00:50,000 --> 00:00:53,000
Our message is selected from the set of all possible messages.

17
00:00:53,000 --> 00:00:57,000
We have some other message we'll call m*, also selected from M.

18
00:00:57,000 --> 00:00:59,000
We don't know if M is equal to m*.

19
00:00:59,000 --> 00:01:03,000
Both of these we could think of being drawn from the set of messages.

20
00:01:03,000 --> 00:01:06,000
We have some key drawn from the set of possible keys.

21
00:01:06,000 --> 00:01:12,000
For this quiz your goal is to understand how we can formally define what a perfect cipher is.

22
00:01:12,000 --> 00:01:15,000
This is the scenario: we have an attacker whose heard of cipher text.

23
00:01:15,000 --> 00:01:19,000
We want to know that by hearing just the cipher text the attacker has learned

24
00:01:19,000 --> 00:01:21,000
nothing new about the message.

25
00:01:21,000 --> 00:01:23,000
We've introduced some notation here.

26
00:01:23,000 --> 00:01:26,000
We have a set of possible messages--the uppercase M.

27
00:01:26,000 --> 00:01:31,000
We can select lowercase message m*. Those are both messages selected from M.

28
00:01:31,000 --> 00:01:37,000
The attacker's goal would be to tell is the intercepted cipher text the same as message m*.

29
00:01:37,000 --> 00:01:40,000
That's the attacker's guess.

30
00:01:40,000 --> 00:01:44,000
We have encryption using some key selected from the set of all possible keys.

31
00:01:44,000 --> 00:01:48,000
We don't know what the key is. Here are the possible choices.

media.name: cs387_unit1_19_s_Lorenz-Cipher-Machine
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:04,000
The answer is actually both the first and the third 

2
00:00:04,000 --> 00:00:08,000
are likely to be significantly greater than 1/2. The second is not.

3
00:00:08,000 --> 00:00:12,000
Assuming the keys have as many 0s and 1s 

4
00:00:12,000 --> 00:00:15,000
as the good key rotor should be designed to have,

5
00:00:15,000 --> 00:00:17,000
this is likely to be equal to 1/2.

6
00:00:17,000 --> 00:00:20,000
There is no reason to expect it to be greater

7
00:00:20,000 --> 00:00:23,000
 than 1/2 any more likely than it'd be less than 1/2.

8
00:00:23,000 --> 00:00:26,000
We're XORing two consecutive key bits.

9
00:00:26,000 --> 00:00:29,000
The other two are different from 1/2.

10
00:00:29,000 --> 00:00:33,000
This is what gives us the opportunity and what gave Bletchley Park the insight

11
00:00:33,000 --> 00:00:35,000
needed to break the cipher.

12
00:00:35,000 --> 00:00:38,000
For the third one, this followed from the structure of the machine.

13
00:00:38,000 --> 00:00:43,000
When the S wheels advance this probability is about 1/2,

14
00:00:43,000 --> 00:00:46,000
but when they don't advance ΔS is always 0.

15
00:00:46,000 --> 00:00:51,000
This means the probability that ΔS is 0 is significantly greater than 1/2.

16
00:00:51,000 --> 00:00:57,000
It turns out for the structure of the Lorenz machine it's about 0.73.

17
00:00:57,000 --> 00:01:00,000
To know that you'd have to look in more detail at the structure of the M wheels

18
00:01:00,000 --> 00:01:03,000
to know how frequently the S wheels advance.

19
00:01:03,000 --> 00:01:06,000
When they don't advance we know the result is 0.

20
00:01:06,000 --> 00:01:09,000
When they do advance about half the time the result will be 0.

21
00:01:09,000 --> 00:01:15,000
Getting the first one right required a little more linguistic insight.

22
00:01:15,000 --> 00:01:22,000
The reason this is greater than 1/2 depends on subsequent message letters.

23
00:01:22,000 --> 00:01:25,000
If adjacent letters in the message are the same,

24
00:01:25,000 --> 00:01:28,000
that ensures that ΔM is equal to 0.

25
00:01:28,000 --> 00:01:32,000
It turns out that this is a property that many languages have.

26
00:01:32,000 --> 00:01:34,000
You can see that English has it.

27
00:01:34,000 --> 00:01:39,000
We have repeated letters here. We also have some repeated letters in "wheels."

28
00:01:39,000 --> 00:01:44,000
It's more like that you would expect by just the normal letter distribution 

29
00:01:44,000 --> 00:01:47,000
for subsequent letters to be identical.

30
00:01:47,000 --> 00:01:53,000
It turns out that this is a property of German that about 3.3% of digraphs,

31
00:01:53,000 --> 00:01:57,000
meaning two adjacent letters are the same letter.

32
00:01:57,000 --> 00:02:00,000
That means the probability that the messages are equal--

33
00:02:00,000 --> 00:02:03,000
well, they could be equal for lots of other reasons,

34
00:02:03,000 --> 00:02:10,000
but this bias is towards being more likely to be zero than non-zero.

35
00:02:10,000 --> 00:02:16,000
It turns out that that's 0.61 probability for German.

36
00:02:16,000 --> 00:02:21,000
Both of these are numbers that you didn't have enough information to guess on your own.

37
00:02:21,000 --> 00:02:24,000
You would need to have a analysis of German text to know 

38
00:02:24,000 --> 00:02:26,000
that this is the probability here,

39
00:02:26,000 --> 00:02:30,000
and you would need a lot more details on the M wheels to be able to get that.

40
00:02:30,000 --> 00:02:33,000
Don't feel bad if you didn't get this quiz correct,

41
00:02:33,000 --> 00:02:35,000
although the structure of the machine should have been enough to guess

42
00:02:35,000 --> 00:02:37,000
that this is greater than 1/2,

43
00:02:37,000 --> 00:02:40,000
and if you're familiar with German 

44
00:02:40,000 --> 00:02:43,000
or could guess that it has properties similar to English, 

45
00:02:43,000 --> 00:02:46,000
you might have been able to get this one as well.

media.name: cs387_unit1_07_s_One-Time-Pad
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:01,000
So the key point to notice here--

2
00:00:01,000 --> 00:00:05,000
and this is why the One-Time Pad provides perfect secrecy--

3
00:00:05,000 --> 00:00:09,000
is that for any given ciphertext we can produce any message we want 

4
00:00:09,000 --> 00:00:10,000
by picking different keys.

5
00:00:10,000 --> 00:00:12,000
That means that if we just have the ciphertext, 

6
00:00:12,000 --> 00:00:15,000
we haven't learned anything at all about the message.

7
00:00:15,000 --> 00:00:17,000
The way to produce the message 'BS' from this ciphertext--

8
00:00:17,000 --> 00:00:23,000
well, we just need to change this first letter to be one below 

9
00:00:23,000 --> 00:00:24,000
where C was.

10
00:00:24,000 --> 00:00:27,000
So that means we want to change this bit 

11
00:00:27,000 --> 00:00:30,000
to be a 0 instead of a 1 in the output.

12
00:00:30,000 --> 00:00:33,000
That means we need to flip one bit in the key.

13
00:00:33,000 --> 00:00:34,000
So we'll need to change this key bit

14
00:00:34,000 --> 00:00:37,000
to be a 1 instead of a 0.

15
00:00:37,000 --> 00:00:39,000
Everything else will be the same.

16
00:00:39,000 --> 00:00:41,000
This will change the output letter by one.

17
00:00:41,000 --> 00:00:44,000
So if you guessed this key instead of the correct key,

18
00:00:44,000 --> 00:00:46,000
we get what looks like a fairly reasonable message out

19
00:00:46,000 --> 00:00:49,000
but it would be one off from the one that was there.

20
00:00:49,000 --> 00:00:52,000
And--in fact, we could get any possible message we want

21
00:00:52,000 --> 00:00:53,000
by guessing different keys.

22
00:00:53,000 --> 00:00:55,000
So this is what's called a One-Time Pad,

23
00:00:55,000 --> 00:01:00,000
and that notion of a One-Time Pad goes back until at least 1882.

24
00:01:00,000 --> 00:01:05,000
It was discovered quite recently that it was known about this early.

25
00:01:05,000 --> 00:01:08,000
There were One-Time Pads used in World War I,

26
00:01:08,000 --> 00:01:13,000
and used in many other contexts since then.

27
00:01:13,000 --> 00:01:16,000
The notion of the One-Time Pad being known this early

28
00:01:16,000 --> 00:01:19,000
 was only discovered last year by Steven Bellovin.

29
00:01:19,000 --> 00:01:21,000
What made a One-Time Pad really interesting was the analysis

30
00:01:21,000 --> 00:01:24,000
that Claude Shannon did.

31
00:01:24,000 --> 00:01:27,000
Claude Shannon was the father of information theory.

32
00:01:27,000 --> 00:01:30,000
He did some of the first theoretical work in cryptography.

33
00:01:30,000 --> 00:01:33,000
During World War II, he studied communication,

34
00:01:33,000 --> 00:01:36,000
and he also studied theory of secret systems,

35
00:01:36,000 --> 00:01:38,000
and he wrote this paper, which was the first paper

36
00:01:38,000 --> 00:01:41,000
that really understood in a theoretical way

37
00:01:41,000 --> 00:01:43,000
what it means for a cipher to be good,

38
00:01:43,000 --> 00:01:46,000
and this paper was written during World War II.

39
00:01:46,000 --> 00:01:49,000
It was classified and released in 1949.

40
00:01:49,000 --> 00:01:50,000
So what we're going to look at next is

41
00:01:50,000 --> 00:01:53,000
how you formally reason about a cipher being secure

42
00:01:53,000 --> 00:01:57,000
and why the One-Time Pad has all the security properties

43
00:01:57,000 --> 00:02:00,000
that make it a perfect cipher.

nuggets.name: Otp Is A Perfect Cipher Pt 1 Solution

media.name: cs387_unit1_13_s_OTP-is-a-Perfect-Cipher-pt-1
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:03,000
The answer is there is always exactly 1.

2
00:00:03,000 --> 00:00:08,000
For any message ciphertext pair, there is one key that maps that message to that ciphertext.

3
00:00:08,000 --> 00:00:11,000
We can see that thinking about the nature of the one-time pad.

4
00:00:11,000 --> 00:00:13,000
Suppose we just have 1-bit messages.

5
00:00:13,000 --> 00:00:16,000
We have messages 0 and 1.

6
00:00:16,000 --> 00:00:20,000
Then the key 0 will map 0 to 0.

7
00:00:20,000 --> 00:00:25,000
The key 1 will map 1 to 0. The key 0 will map 1 to 1.

8
00:00:25,000 --> 00:00:28,000
This works for any length message and any length key.

9
00:00:28,000 --> 00:00:31,000
Note that the length of the key and the length of the message scale the same way.

10
00:00:31,000 --> 00:00:36,000
If we had 2-bit messages there would be four different keys

11
00:00:36,000 --> 00:00:39,000
that would map each message to each different ciphertext.

12
00:00:39,000 --> 00:00:42,000
If we had 2-bit messages, there would also be one key

13
00:00:42,000 --> 00:00:45,000
that maps each message to each different ciphertext.

14
00:00:45,000 --> 00:00:50,000
For example, the key that maps 00 to 10 would be the key 11.

15
00:00:50,000 --> 00:00:53,000
That means we can compute this probability,

16
00:00:53,000 --> 00:00:56,000
summing over all the messages summing over all the keys

17
00:00:56,000 --> 00:01:03,000
where we've got the probability that that key encrypts that message to the given ciphertext.

18
00:01:03,000 --> 00:01:08,000
We need to divide this by the space, which is the size of the messages 

19
00:01:08,000 --> 00:01:10,000
times the size of the keys.

20
00:01:10,000 --> 00:01:12,000
Now whats the value of the summation?

21
00:01:12,000 --> 00:01:17,000
We know for a given message there is exactly one key that maps it to that ciphertext.

22
00:01:17,000 --> 00:01:20,000
This is one, and we're summing over all the messages,

23
00:01:20,000 --> 00:01:23,000
summing the value of 1.

24
00:01:23,000 --> 00:01:27,000
That means we're going to get the number of messages divided by

25
00:01:27,000 --> 00:01:29,000
the number of messages times the number of keys.

26
00:01:29,000 --> 00:01:32,000
That's equal to 1 over the number of keys.

27
00:01:32,000 --> 00:01:36,000
That's the probability of event B, which is probability 

28
00:01:36,000 --> 00:01:39,000
that some message encrypts to some key.

29
00:01:39,000 --> 00:01:42,000
Notice this is computed over all the messages. 

30
00:01:42,000 --> 00:01:45,000
That's over the distribution.

nuggets.name: Otp Is A Perfect Cipher Pt 2

media.name: cs387_unit1_14_q_OTP-is-a-Perfect-Cipher-pt-2
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:04,000
But what we need to do now is consider this particular message M*.

2
00:00:04,000 --> 00:00:09,000
We want to compute the probability of the intersection of those events,

3
00:00:09,000 --> 00:00:14,000
that the selected message is M* and the message encrypts to C.

4
00:00:14,000 --> 00:00:18,000
I'm going to make that a quiz and see if you can figure out what that is yourself.

5
00:00:18,000 --> 00:00:20,000
Here are your choices.

6
00:00:20,000 --> 00:00:23,000
See if you can figure out what the probability of M equals M* 

7
00:00:23,000 --> 00:00:26,000
intersected with the encryption of M equals C.

media.name: cs387_unit1_18_q_Intercepting-messages
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:04,000
These links started to be used in May 1941.

2
00:00:04,000 --> 00:00:08,000
In August 1941, the Allies had a big break.

3
00:00:08,000 --> 00:00:14,000
An operating was sending a message starting with the initial configuration.

4
00:00:14,000 --> 00:00:16,000
These configurations came from code books.  

5
00:00:16,000 --> 00:00:21,000
The recipients at the other end needed to know that the configuration for that day was.

6
00:00:21,000 --> 00:00:24,000
But these could be distributed securely and 

7
00:00:24,000 --> 00:00:27,000
were much smaller than needing to distribute the key sequence.

8
00:00:27,000 --> 00:00:30,000
Once you had the starting configuration, you could transmit

9
00:00:30,000 --> 00:00:33,000
an arbitrarily large message if this assumption that the key was 

10
00:00:33,000 --> 00:00:36,000
completely unpredictable was true.

11
00:00:36,000 --> 00:00:39,000
In this case the operator sent the message.

12
00:00:39,000 --> 00:00:41,000
The receiver did not receive it.

13
00:00:41,000 --> 00:00:45,000
The receiver said, "Garbled transmission, please resend."

14
00:00:45,000 --> 00:00:51,000
So the annoyed operator had to send the message again for the insecure channel,

15
00:00:51,000 --> 00:00:53,000
and this time it was received okay.

16
00:00:53,000 --> 00:00:56,000
If this is exactly what happened, it would have been fine.

17
00:00:56,000 --> 00:00:58,000
These would be exactly the same.

18
00:00:58,000 --> 00:01:01,000
We restarted the machine in the same configuration.

19
00:01:01,000 --> 00:01:03,000
But what happened was a little different.

20
00:01:03,000 --> 00:01:05,000
The operator got a little lazy the second time.

21
00:01:05,000 --> 00:01:08,000
The operator was annoyed having to retransmit the message,

22
00:01:08,000 --> 00:01:12,000
so instead of sending exactly the same message sent a slightly different message.

23
00:01:12,000 --> 00:01:18,000
That meant that there was a slightly different ciphertext than we had the previous time.

24
00:01:18,000 --> 00:01:24,000
Both of these messages were intercepted.

25
00:01:24,000 --> 00:01:30,000
That means the Allies now had access to both C and C'.

26
00:01:30,000 --> 00:01:32,000
They didn't know anything about the key.

27
00:01:32,000 --> 00:01:34,000
They didn't know anything about the original messages.

28
00:01:34,000 --> 00:01:37,000
Well, maybe they knew a little bit about the original message.

29
00:01:37,000 --> 00:01:42,000
That's what's going to help them given these two ciphertexts to figure out both the key,

30
00:01:42,000 --> 00:01:45,000
and, once they have the key, the structure of the Lorenz.

31
00:01:45,000 --> 00:01:51,000
What is the result of XORing these two messages?

32
00:01:51,000 --> 00:01:58,000
That means for each bit, we go through the bits to the messages XORing each bit.

33
00:01:58,000 --> 00:02:02,000
I want to introduce a new variable here.

34
00:02:02,000 --> 00:02:07,000
The key that the machine generates we'll call K.

35
00:02:07,000 --> 00:02:12,000
That's the key that the machine generates starting from configuration C0.

36
00:02:12,000 --> 00:02:17,000
Which one of these is the value that the interceptor would get 

37
00:02:17,000 --> 00:02:21,000
by XORing the two intercepted ciphertexts.

media.name: cs387_unit1_08_q_Proving-Security
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:04,000
We saw earlier how we could prove correctness, and correctness is easy to show.

2
00:00:04,000 --> 00:00:06,000
Proving security is really hard.

3
00:00:06,000 --> 00:00:09,000
This property of the one-time pad that we can change the key and that leads

4
00:00:09,000 --> 00:00:15,000
to a different message, is the reason why it is secure.

5
00:00:15,000 --> 00:00:18,000
But first I want to talk about how to prove security in general.

6
00:00:18,000 --> 00:00:21,000
Then we'll come back to the problem of how do we prove that the one-time pad

7
00:00:21,000 --> 00:00:24,000
is actually a perfect cipher.

8
00:00:24,000 --> 00:00:27,000
How can we argue that a cipher is secure?

9
00:00:27,000 --> 00:00:29,000
This is a really hard problem.

10
00:00:29,000 --> 00:00:33,000
I'm going to start with a quiz, and it will definitely require some guesswork.

11
00:00:33,000 --> 00:00:35,000
See if you think it through before I explain the answer.

12
00:00:35,000 --> 00:00:38,000
I'm going to give you give possible ways someone might argue 

13
00:00:38,000 --> 00:00:40,000
that a cipher is secure.

14
00:00:40,000 --> 00:00:43,000
For this quiz, your goal is to order the arguments below

15
00:00:43,000 --> 00:00:47,000
by how effective they are in convincing someone that a cipher is secure.

16
00:00:47,000 --> 00:00:52,000
Use 1 to indicate the best argument and 4 to indicate the worst argument.

17
00:00:52,000 --> 00:00:55,000
The choices are many very smart people were highly-motivated to break

18
00:00:55,000 --> 00:00:57,000
the cipher but were not able to.

19
00:00:57,000 --> 00:00:59,000
That means it must be secure.

20
00:00:59,000 --> 00:01:03,000
The second choice is there are 834 quadrillion possible keys, so it must be secure.

21
00:01:03,000 --> 00:01:06,000
The third choice here is a mathematical proof that's been accepted by experts

22
00:01:06,000 --> 00:01:08,000
that shows the cipher is secure.

23
00:01:08,000 --> 00:01:11,000
The forth choice is here is a strong argument why breaking the cipher

24
00:01:11,000 --> 00:01:15,000
is at least as hard as some problem we already believe is hard.

25
00:01:15,000 --> 00:01:18,000
This is a bit of a unfair question, since we haven't talked about this yet.

26
00:01:18,000 --> 00:01:22,000
I think it's useful for you to think about it on your own before I talk about it.

27
00:01:22,000 --> 00:01:27,000
See if you can figure out which of these arguments are most effective.

media.name: cs387_unit1_10_q_Probability-Review-pt-2
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:02,000
 The next term I want to define is an event.

2
00:00:02,000 --> 00:00:07,000
You might think of landing on the edge or landing on tails being an event.

3
00:00:07,000 --> 00:00:13,000
We can define an event a bit more broadly that it's a subset of outcomes from the distribution.

4
00:00:13,000 --> 00:00:18,000
So an example of an event would be landing on heads,

5
00:00:18,000 --> 00:00:21,000
