and landing on heads as an event is just a set of the outcome {H}.

6
00:00:21,000 --> 00:00:25,000
We could define then valid for a valid coin toss, 

7
00:00:25,000 --> 00:00:29,000
and that's the set of outcomes {H, T}.

8
00:00:29,000 --> 00:00:34,000
The probability of an event is just the sum of the probabilities of all of the outcomes

9
00:00:34,000 --> 00:00:35,000
in that subset.

10
00:00:35,000 --> 00:00:39,000
So the probabililty of an event A is the sum of all the outcomes in A

11
00:00:39,000 --> 00:00:41,000
of the probability of that outcome.

12
00:00:41,000 --> 00:00:45,000
So that should be enough to figure out, what is the probability of a valid toss?

13
00:00:45,000 --> 00:00:54,000
I'll remind you that we defined the probability of heads as 0.49999,

14
00:00:54,000 --> 00:01:01,000
and the probability of tails as 0.49999.

15
00:01:01,000 --> 00:01:04,000
So what's the probability of a valid coin toss?

media.name: cs387_unit1_12_s_Perfect-Cipher
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:02,000
The answer is the second one.

2
00:00:02,000 --> 00:00:04,000
Here we're using conditional probability.

3
00:00:04,000 --> 00:00:07,000
The event that we saw was the cipher text.

4
00:00:07,000 --> 00:00:09,000
That's the encryption of m.

5
00:00:09,000 --> 00:00:13,000
What we want to know whether the message is equal to m*.

6
00:00:13,000 --> 00:00:17,000
Both of those are drawn from the set of all possible messages.

7
00:00:17,000 --> 00:00:24,000
In order for the attacker to know nothing is the same as the probability that the message is m*

8
00:00:24,000 --> 00:00:26,000
without knowing the cipher text.

9
00:00:26,000 --> 00:00:31,000
The first answer would be correct if, a priori, the attacker knew nothing about the messages.

10
00:00:31,000 --> 00:00:34,000
All the attacker knows is each message is equally likely.

11
00:00:34,000 --> 00:00:37,000
In that case, the probability that the message is m* 

12
00:00:37,000 --> 00:00:41,000
would be 1 over the number of possible messages not depending on the cipher text.

13
00:00:41,000 --> 00:00:43,000
The problem is the attacker might know something more. 

14
00:00:43,000 --> 00:00:46,000
They might know that some messages are more likely than others.

15
00:00:46,000 --> 00:00:48,000
In most realistic scenarios this is the case.

16
00:00:48,000 --> 00:00:52,000
The attacker knows that the message is likely to be a valid sentence in English.

17
00:00:52,000 --> 00:00:59,000
Very few possible bit sequences correspond to that, so all messages are not equally likely.

18
00:00:59,000 --> 00:01:02,000
That's why choice 1 is not the definition we want.

19
00:01:02,000 --> 00:01:06,000
We want choice 2 where whatever the attacker already knew about 

20
00:01:06,000 --> 00:01:13,000
the probability of the message as m* is not affected in any way by seeing the cipher text.

21
00:01:13,000 --> 00:01:16,000
That's our definition of a perfect cipher.

22
00:01:16,000 --> 00:01:20,000
Now the question is can we prove that the one-time pad has this property.

nuggets.name: Otp Is A Perfect Cipher Pt 3

media.name: cs387_unit1_15_l_OTP-is-a-Perfect-Cipher-pt-3
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:05,000
We showed earlier that this was 1/K--1 over the size of K.

2
00:00:05,000 --> 00:00:13,000
Now we've shown that the probability of M equals M* is equal to the probability 

3
00:00:13,000 --> 00:00:20,000
the message is M* divided by the K.

4
00:00:20,000 --> 00:00:22,000
We've shown these two things. 

5
00:00:22,000 --> 00:00:25,000
Now we just need to plug them into our conditional probability formula.

6
00:00:25,000 --> 00:00:29,000
We're going to have this on top, and we're going to divide that by the probability of B,

7
00:00:29,000 --> 00:00:31,000
which is 1 over K.

8
00:00:31,000 --> 00:00:35,000
The "over Ks" will cancel out, leaving us with the probability 

9
00:00:35,000 --> 00:00:38,000
that the message is equal to M*.

10
00:00:38,000 --> 00:00:42,000
That's exactly our definition of a perfect cipher.

11
00:00:42,000 --> 00:00:46,000
We can conclude that the one-time pad is a perfect cipher.

12
00:00:46,000 --> 00:00:49,000
It exactly satisfies the definition of a perfect cipher 

13
00:00:49,000 --> 00:00:53,000
where the cipher text reveals nothing at all about the key.

14
00:00:53,000 --> 00:00:55,000
You might think the class should be over.

15
00:00:55,000 --> 00:00:59,000
We've achieved our goal of perfect secrecy using a cipher 

16
00:00:59,000 --> 00:01:05,000
that was invented over 100 years ago and is actually provably perfectly secret.

17
00:01:05,000 --> 00:01:07,000
We're not going quite done yet. 

18
00:01:07,000 --> 00:01:10,000
There are some pretty serious problems with the one-time pad.

19
00:01:10,000 --> 00:01:13,000
One problem is that it's malleable.

20
00:01:13,000 --> 00:01:17,000
What malleable means is if Alice sends her ciphertext to Bob,

21
00:01:17,000 --> 00:01:21,000
and our evil interceptor--this times it's not just an eavesdropped,

22
00:01:21,000 --> 00:01:23,000
it's an eavesdropper with a hammer.

23
00:01:23,000 --> 00:01:26,000
If our interceptor has control over the network,

24
00:01:26,000 --> 00:01:30,000
and instead of just being an eavesdropper can be an active attacker.

25
00:01:30,000 --> 00:01:35,000
An active attacker means they can actually change messages on the network.

26
00:01:35,000 --> 00:01:39,000
The message that arrives at Bob is not C. It's C'.

27
00:01:39,000 --> 00:01:45,000
Because at the perfect cipher, the attacker can't learn anything new about the message

28
00:01:45,000 --> 00:01:47,000
from C, but she could modify it.

29
00:01:47,000 --> 00:01:49,000
Maybe she had a pretty good guess. 

30
00:01:49,000 --> 00:01:51,000
Maybe there was a number in the message somewhere 

31
00:01:51,000 --> 00:01:53,000
or something that she wanted to change.

32
00:01:53,000 --> 00:01:56,000
Well, she could flip the bits at that part of the message,

33
00:01:56,000 --> 00:01:59,000
change the ciphertext that Bob receives to C.

34
00:01:59,000 --> 00:02:04,000
It would decrypt, and with the one-time pad encryption and decryption are the same function.

35
00:02:04,000 --> 00:02:08,000
The decryption of C' would be M'.

36
00:02:08,000 --> 00:02:12,000
The attacker can actually control the difference between M and M',

37
00:02:12,000 --> 00:02:15,000
because the way the one-time pad works is just XOR.

38
00:02:15,000 --> 00:02:19,000
The attacker could decide whatever difference she wants to introduce in the message.

39
00:02:19,000 --> 00:02:22,000
This is a dangerous property for a cipher to have.

40
00:02:22,000 --> 00:02:27,000
Another big problem with the one-time pad is that it's very impractical.

41
00:02:27,000 --> 00:02:31,000
The real reason that it's impractical is because the keys have to be 

42
00:02:31,000 --> 00:02:35,000
as long as the messages, and we can never reuse the key.

43
00:02:35,000 --> 00:02:38,000
The is this property that the number of possible keys 

44
00:02:38,000 --> 00:02:41,000
is equal to the number of possible messages.

45
00:02:41,000 --> 00:02:46,000
Maybe what we should try to do is to find a more practical perfect cipher.

46
00:02:46,000 --> 00:02:50,000
Unfortunately, Claude Shannon proved that that's not possible.

47
00:02:50,000 --> 00:02:54,000
That's what we're going to look at next is why this property that the key space

48
00:02:54,000 --> 00:02:56,000
has to be at least as big as the message space i

49
00:02:56,000 --> 00:02:59,000
s a requirement for a cipher being perfect.

media.name: cs387_unit1_16_q_Perfect-Cipher-is-Impractical
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:05,000
The theorem essentially says is that if a cipher is perfect, it must have this property.

2
00:00:05,000 --> 00:00:10,000
It must be impractical in the sense that the number of possible keys

3
00:00:10,000 --> 00:00:14,000
 must be at least as big as the number of possible messages.

4
00:00:14,000 --> 00:00:16,000
We saw for the one-time pad that they were equal.

5
00:00:16,000 --> 00:00:20,000
We can always remove possible messages from the message set

6
00:00:20,000 --> 00:00:23,000
so there's no problem with adding more keys.

7
00:00:23,000 --> 00:00:26,000
The problem is we need to have at least as many keys as messages.

8
00:00:26,000 --> 00:00:28,000
Let's prove this property.

9
00:00:28,000 --> 00:00:31,000
We're going to prove it by contradiction.

10
00:00:31,000 --> 00:00:34,000
We're going to start by assuming that we do have a perfect cipher

11
00:00:34,000 --> 00:00:37,000
that does not satisfy this property.

12
00:00:37,000 --> 00:00:40,000
Suppose we do have some perfect cipher--we'll call it "E"--

13
00:00:40,000 --> 00:00:45,000
where the number of possible messages is greater than the number of possible keys.

14
00:00:45,000 --> 00:00:51,000
There is some ciphertext--call it c0 element of the set of possible ciphertexts.

15
00:00:51,000 --> 00:00:54,000
Let's assume that that ciphertext is possible.

16
00:00:54,000 --> 00:00:57,000
We know that there must be such a cipher text.

17
00:00:57,000 --> 00:01:02,000
There is some key that encrypts some message to c0.

18
00:01:02,000 --> 00:01:09,000
The probability that a message and key get encrypted to this ciphertext is greater than 0.

19
00:01:09,000 --> 00:01:11,000
We know that such a ciphertext must exist.

20
00:01:11,000 --> 00:01:13,000
Now we have a our ciphertext c0.

21
00:01:13,000 --> 00:01:15,000
Let's try decrypting that.

22
00:01:15,000 --> 00:01:17,000
We'll decrypt it with all keys in the key space.

23
00:01:17,000 --> 00:01:20,000
We haven't mentioned what the decryption function is.

24
00:01:20,000 --> 00:01:23,000
For the one-time pad it's exactly the same as the encryption function.

25
00:01:23,000 --> 00:01:25,000
For this we don't want to assume this. I could be any function.

26
00:01:25,000 --> 00:01:29,000
We'll assume there is some function D that is our decryption function.

27
00:01:29,000 --> 00:01:36,000
Since our cipher is correct--in order to be perfect it has to both be correct and perfectly secure.

28
00:01:36,000 --> 00:01:40,000
That means the decryption function must have the property that if we decrypt

29
00:01:40,000 --> 00:01:45,000
a message encrypted with the same key, we always get the same message out.

30
00:01:45,000 --> 00:01:48,000
We don't need to know anything else about the decryption function than that.

31
00:01:48,000 --> 00:01:52,000
We shouldn't assume anything, because all we're trying to do is show that 

32
00:01:52,000 --> 00:01:58,000
there is no possible choice for E that is both a correct encryption function and a perfect cipher.

33
00:01:58,000 --> 00:02:03,000
Now what happens when we decrypt c0 with all possible keys?

34
00:02:03,000 --> 00:02:07,000
Well, we're going to look at the set of messages that we can produce.

35
00:02:07,000 --> 00:02:13,000
We'll call M0 the set of messages that we get by unioning over all possible keys

36
00:02:13,000 --> 00:02:17,000
the result of decrypting the cipher text c0.

37
00:02:17,000 --> 00:02:20,000
This models what an attacker would do.

38
00:02:20,000 --> 00:02:24,000
They've intercepted some ciphertext. They're trying all possible keys.

39
00:02:24,000 --> 00:02:27,000
This is what a brute-force attacker would do.

40
00:02:27,000 --> 00:02:31,000
Looking at all the possible messages that can be produced.

41
00:02:31,000 --> 00:02:34,000
Now I want you to think about which of these statements are true.

42
00:02:34,000 --> 00:02:37,000
Check all the statements that must be true.

media.name: cs387_unit1_08_s_Proving-Security
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:02,000
Here what I think the best answer is.

2
00:00:02,000 --> 00:00:05,000
The best possibility is that we do have a mathematical proof 

3
00:00:05,000 --> 00:00:10,000
that follows standard rules of deduction that shows that the cipher is secure.

4
00:00:10,000 --> 00:00:13,000
There are very few ciphers that we can actually get that for.

5
00:00:13,000 --> 00:00:15,000
One actually is the one-time pad.

6
00:00:15,000 --> 00:00:18,000
We'll see later this unit how to prove in a mathematical sense

7
00:00:18,000 --> 00:00:21,000
 that it has a very strong security property.

8
00:00:21,000 --> 00:00:24,000
The next best one is the last one, 

9
00:00:24,000 --> 00:00:27,000
which is to show in a formal way 

10
00:00:27,000 --> 00:00:32,000
why this cipher is at least as hard as some other problem.

11
00:00:32,000 --> 00:00:35,000
We'll talk about reduction proofs more later in this course.

12
00:00:35,000 --> 00:00:39,000
The basic premise here is that there is some other problem that we have good reasons

13
00:00:39,000 --> 00:00:41,000
to believe is always already hard.

14
00:00:41,000 --> 00:00:44,000
Then we're going to show that if we could break the cipher, 

15
00:00:44,000 --> 00:00:48,000
we could solve that other problem that we already have good reasons to believe is hard.

16
00:00:48,000 --> 00:00:50,000
The next best is this one--

17
00:00:50,000 --> 00:00:54,000
that many smart highly-motivated people tried to break but couldn't.

18
00:00:54,000 --> 00:00:57,000
This is often the best we can do.

19
00:00:57,000 --> 00:01:00,000
For the best symmetric ciphers that are in use today

20
00:01:00,000 --> 00:01:03,000
 this is really the reason that they're argued secure.

21
00:01:03,000 --> 00:01:07,000
There may be formal arguments that show why they resist particular attacks,

22
00:01:07,000 --> 00:01:10,000
and that's part of smart people trying to break ciphers,

23
00:01:10,000 --> 00:01:14,000
knowing all the known best-case attacks and trying them against the cipher

24
00:01:14,000 --> 00:01:16,000
and seeing that the cipher resists them.

25
00:01:16,000 --> 00:01:20,000
But ultimately the best we can do is show that 

26
00:01:20,000 --> 00:01:22,000
we think it's secure because it has these properties,

27
00:01:22,000 --> 00:01:24,000
and lots of smart people weren't able to break it.

28
00:01:24,000 --> 00:01:26,000
But that's not a very satisfying way to know it's secure.

29
00:01:26,000 --> 00:01:29,000
We're certainly much rather have the strong mathematical proof.

30
00:01:29,000 --> 00:01:33,000
The worst possible argument here is the key-space argument.

31
00:01:33,000 --> 00:01:36,000
This one is often made incorrectly.

32
00:01:36,000 --> 00:01:40,000
The number of keys gives you an upper bound on the difficulty to break the cipher,

33
00:01:40,000 --> 00:01:42,000
because at worst the attacker could try all the keys.

34
00:01:42,000 --> 00:01:45,000
That's not true for the one-time pad, as we saw.

35
00:01:45,000 --> 00:01:47,000
Trying keys gives you perfectly sensible messages.

36
00:01:47,000 --> 00:01:49,000
You'll eventually see all possible messages.

37
00:01:49,000 --> 00:01:52,000
You can't know which key is correct.

38
00:01:52,000 --> 00:01:55,000
For ciphers where the key space is smaller than the message space,

39
00:01:55,000 --> 00:01:58,000
you could try keys and have a good likelihood

40
00:01:58,000 --> 00:02:02,000
if the key leads to a sensible message, that that's the right message.

41
00:02:02,000 --> 00:02:05,000
This gives you an upper bound on how hard it is to break a cipher.

42
00:02:05,000 --> 00:02:07,000
It doesn't give you a lower bound.

43
00:02:07,000 --> 00:02:10,000
The fact that you have a large number of possible keys doesn't mean the cipher is secure.

44
00:02:10,000 --> 00:02:14,000
We can always add to the key space without  increasing the difficulty in breaking a cipher.

45
00:02:14,000 --> 00:02:17,000
We'll see many ciphers with very large key spaces

46
00:02:17,000 --> 00:02:20,000
that are completely insecure.

47
00:02:20,000 --> 00:02:23,000
Our best possible argument is to have a mathematical proof.

48
00:02:23,000 --> 00:02:27,000
That's what Claude Shannon was able to do for the one-time pad.

49
00:02:27,000 --> 00:02:30,000
It's really a fairly unusual case where we can get 

50
00:02:30,000 --> 00:02:33,000
a mathematical proof that's that strong.

media.name: cs387_unit1_11_q_Probability-Review-pt-3
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:03,000
The next concept I want to talk about is conditional probability.

2
00:00:03,000 --> 00:00:09,000
This is the one we're going to need to use to prove that the one-time pad is perfectly secure.

3
00:00:09,000 --> 00:00:12,000
Here's the definition of conditional probability.

4
00:00:12,000 --> 00:00:15,000
If we have two events--we'll call them A and B--

5
00:00:15,000 --> 00:00:17,000
and they're in the same probability space,

6
00:00:17,000 --> 00:00:20,000
the conditional probability of B given that A occured

7
00:00:20,000 --> 00:00:26,000
is written like this: it's the probability of B given A--so we use the bar

8
00:00:26,000 --> 00:00:30,000
to indicate conditional probability--and it's defined by this formula.

9
00:00:30,000 --> 00:00:33,000
It's the probability of A intersected with B

10
00:00:33,000 --> 00:00:35,000
divided by the probability of A.

11
00:00:35,000 --> 00:00:38,000
To get an intuition for that, let's look at these sets.

12
00:00:38,000 --> 00:00:42,000
Here's our universe omega. That's all events.

13
00:00:42,000 --> 00:00:46,000
Our question is given that we know A occurred,

14
00:00:46,000 --> 00:00:48,000
what's the probability of A.

15
00:00:48,000 --> 00:00:53,000
The fact that A occurred means the rest of our probability set doesn't matter.

16
00:00:53,000 --> 00:00:57,000
We're only considering the outcomes where A occurred.

17
00:00:57,000 --> 00:00:59,000
That's the set for A.

18
00:00:59,000 --> 00:01:03,000
We want to know what was the probability that B occurred.

19
00:01:03,000 --> 00:01:07,000
Those are the elements in this intersection--the times when B did occur 

20
00:01:07,000 --> 00:01:11,000
divided by the size of the sets A,

21
00:01:11,000 --> 00:01:16,000
which is the probability of A. That's the intuition behind this formula.

22
00:01:16,000 --> 00:01:19,000
Let's see if it makes sense for our example as well.

23
00:01:19,000 --> 00:01:22,000
The question is given that we have a valid coin toss,

24
00:01:22,000 --> 00:01:24,000
what's the probability that it's heads.

25
00:01:24,000 --> 00:01:27,000
I'll remind you the model we had.

26
00:01:27,000 --> 00:01:33,000
It said the probability of heads is 0.49999 with four 9s.

27
00:01:33,000 --> 00:01:40,000
The probability of tails is 0.49999.

28
00:01:40,000 --> 00:01:44,000
The probabiilty of edge is 1 minus the sum of those,

29
00:01:44,000 --> 00:01:49,000
which is 0.00002.

30
00:01:49,000 --> 00:01:55,000
We define valid as the outcomes where it lands on heads or tails not on the edge.

31
00:01:55,000 --> 00:01:57,000
Given that you know a coin toss is valid,

32
00:01:57,000 --> 00:02:01,000
what's the probability that the outcome is heads?

media.name: cs387_unit1_20_q_Importance-of-Keys
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:02,000
Now we've got this great property.

2
00:00:02,000 --> 00:00:05,000
We've got two things that are significantly different from 1/2.

3
00:00:05,000 --> 00:00:08,000
Can we use that to break the cipher?

4
00:00:08,000 --> 00:00:15,000
Now the question is assuming that the probability of ΔK is 0 is still 1/2,

5
00:00:15,000 --> 00:00:21,000
does knowing that these probabilities for ΔM and ΔS being greater than 1/2 help us?

6
00:00:21,000 --> 00:00:25,000
Remember that our ciphertext values that we're intercepting

7
00:00:25,000 --> 00:00:29,000
are the XOR of ΔM, ΔK, and ΔS.

8
00:00:29,000 --> 00:00:32,000
The choices are, yes, that it definitely helps us.

9
00:00:32,000 --> 00:00:35,000
It doesn't necessarily help us, but if we knew something more about K

10
00:00:35,000 --> 00:00:37,000
maybe it would help us.

11
00:00:37,000 --> 00:00:41,000
It doesn't necessarily help us, but if we knew something more about M maybe it would help us.

media.name: cs387_unit1_22_s_Guessing-Keys
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:03,000
[Evans] The answer is 0.55.

2
00:00:03,000 --> 00:00:06,000
The key is 0. We can cancel that out.

3
00:00:06,000 --> 00:00:10,000
So we're left with delta M XORed with delta S.

4
00:00:10,000 --> 00:00:17,000
That could be 0 either if delta M is equal to 0 and delta S is equal to 0,

5
00:00:17,000 --> 00:00:20,000
 then the XOR of 0 and 0 would be 0.

6
00:00:20,000 --> 00:00:23,000
The probability that delta M is 0--well, we know that. 

7
00:00:23,000 --> 00:00:28,000
That's 0.61, and we're going to multiply that by the probability of delta S is 0,

8
00:00:28,000 --> 00:00:31,000
which we know is 0.73.

9
00:00:31,000 --> 00:00:34,000
But that's not the only way delta Z could be 0.

10
00:00:34,000 --> 00:00:38,000
The other way delta Z could be 0 is if both of these are 1.

11
00:00:38,000 --> 00:00:43,000
So it's the probability they're both 0 plus the probability they're both 1,

12
00:00:43,000 --> 00:00:49,000
and these probabilities are 1 minus the probabilities that we have before us,

13
00:00:49,000 --> 00:00:58,000
so it's (1 - 0.61) * (1 - 0.73).

14
00:00:58,000 --> 00:01:03,000
And if you calculate all that, you get 0.5506.

15
00:01:03,000 --> 00:01:05,000
That's probably a little more precise than it should be,

16
00:01:05,000 --> 00:01:08,000
especially because this value is just a guess.

17
00:01:08,000 --> 00:01:11,000
We'd have to do a much more detailed analysis of German

18
00:01:11,000 --> 00:01:15,000
to know whether that probability is really 0.61,

19
00:01:15,000 --> 00:01:19,000
and we'd have to know more about the particular messages that might be encrypted.

20
00:01:19,000 --> 00:01:23,000
But this value is pretty far away from a half.

21
00:01:23,000 --> 00:01:27,000
Any advantage that's that large, if we have a lot of text

22
00:01:27,000 --> 00:01:29,000
we're going to see that pretty clearly.

23
00:01:29,000 --> 00:01:32,000
So if we have enough text, we can count the number of positions

24
00:01:32,000 --> 00:01:35,000
where delta Z is equal to 0.

25
00:01:35,000 --> 00:01:38,000
If it's close to half of them, then it was a wrong guess.

26
00:01:38,000 --> 00:01:42,000
If it's close to 0.55 of them, then we have a good likelihood that that was the right guess.

27
00:01:42,000 --> 00:01:46,000
So now all we have to do is feed in the intercepted messages.

28
00:01:46,000 --> 00:01:51,000
Our guesses for the starting position of the 2 keys,

29
00:01:51,000 --> 00:01:55,000
we need to compute a big summation of these values,

30
00:01:55,000 --> 00:01:59,000
of the delta Z values, with those keys.

31
00:01:59,000 --> 00:02:04,000
And if it's close to the length of the message divided by 2,

32
00:02:04,000 --> 00:02:08,000
that means it was a bad guess. We weren't able to cancel out the key.

33
00:02:08,000 --> 00:02:13,000
If it's close to 0.55 times the size of Z, then it's a good key.

34
00:02:13,000 --> 00:02:16,000
It's likely that that's a good guess.

35
00:02:16,000 --> 00:02:19,000
And then we should be able to use those key guesses

36
00:02:19,000 --> 00:02:22,000
to find out what the actual message was, to decrypt the cipher text.

37
00:02:22,000 --> 00:02:28,000
So this is exactly the problem that what is arguably the first electronic digital computer

38
00:02:28,000 --> 00:02:30,000
was built to solve.

39
00:02:30,000 --> 00:02:33,000
So with this advantage there's a good likelihood 

40
00:02:33,000 --> 00:02:36,000
that you would be able to know when you guess the right key.

41
00:02:36,000 --> 00:02:41,000
You need to try all the configurations of K0 and K1,

42
00:02:41,000 --> 00:02:45,000
and for each one of those configurations you have to compute this double delta.

43
00:02:45,000 --> 00:02:50,000
What we're computing for each configuration is this double delta,

44
00:02:50,000 --> 00:02:52,000
the XOR of 2 deltas,

45
00:02:52,000 --> 00:02:55,000
and that involves computing all these XORs.

46
00:02:55,000 --> 00:03:01,000
We need the XORs of the keys XORed with the messages and the S wheels.

47
00:03:01,000 --> 00:03:04,000
But remember what we're doing is guessing that this is 0.

48
00:03:04,000 --> 00:03:07,000
We don't have any way to predict those S values.

49
00:03:07,000 --> 00:03:12,000
We're producing the key values, and we're XORing those key values

50
00:03:12,000 --> 00:03:14,000
with the intercepted cipher text.

51
00:03:14,000 --> 00:03:17,000
So we need to do these XORs, XORing out the key

52
00:03:17,000 --> 00:03:21,000
and XORing the key with the value of the cipher text.

53
00:03:21,000 --> 00:03:26,000
So for each character we're doing 7 XORs

54
00:03:26,000 --> 00:03:29,000
and we're counting the number of times that's equal to 0.

55
00:03:29,000 --> 00:03:33,000
So multiplying all those together, we know the total number of XORs we need to do,

56
00:03:33,000 --> 00:03:37,000
and we get about 44.5 million.

57
00:03:37,000 --> 00:03:40,000
That's the maximum number that we might need to do.

58
00:03:40,000 --> 00:03:44,000
If we're lucky, we might guess the right configuration right away,

59
00:03:44,000 --> 00:03:46,000
and we could know that that's the right configuration 

60
00:03:46,000 --> 00:03:49,000
by getting the high number of 0s out.

61
00:03:49,000 --> 00:03:52,000
If we're unlucky, we might need all 1271.

62
00:03:52,000 --> 00:03:54,000
Normally, we should expect to need about half of that.

63
00:03:54,000 --> 00:04:00,000
So maybe on average we would need about 25 million XORs to find the configuration,

64
00:04:00,000 --> 00:04:06,000
the correct value of X K1 and K0 for 1 cipher text.

65
00:04:06,000 --> 00:04:13,000
Once we've got K1 and K0, we can do similar things to find K2, K3, and K4,

66
00:04:13,000 --> 00:04:15,000
and then we can decrypt the whole message.

67
00:04:15,000 --> 00:04:18,000
So today, a modern processor runs at 2 gigahertz,

68
00:04:18,000 --> 00:04:21,000
so you're doing 2 billion operations per second,

69
00:04:21,000 --> 00:04:28,000
and 1 operation could include many XORs, possibly 64 XORs or 32 XORs

70
00:04:28,000 --> 00:04:30,000
depending on your processor.

71
00:04:30,000 --> 00:04:34,000
So to do that on a modern processor would take a fraction of a millisecond.

72
00:04:34,000 --> 00:04:38,000
To do that in 1941 was a major technical challenge.

73
00:04:38,000 --> 00:04:41,000
Computers didn't exist yet, but this was the main impetus 

74
00:04:41,000 --> 00:04:46,000
for building what was arguably the first electronic programmable digital computer.

media.name: cs387_unit1_25_l_Advanced-Encryption-Standard
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:03,000
[Evans] We're not going to get into the details of how AES works,

2
00:00:03,000 --> 00:00:06,000
but I want to talk a little bit about the main components of it.

3
00:00:06,000 --> 00:00:10,000
There are 2 main things that go into AES and go into almost all modern block ciphers.

4
00:00:10,000 --> 00:00:15,000
They all involve XORs--we saw that in the one-time pad--

5
00:00:15,000 --> 00:00:19,000
and they're XORing some round key which is generated by a key schedule,

6
00:00:19,000 --> 00:00:23,000
some process of generating new keys for each round.

7
00:00:23,000 --> 00:00:28,000
And then what's going into that, there are 2 main operations.

8
00:00:28,000 --> 00:00:37,000
One is shifts, so permuting bits, and there would be a map that would move bits around.

9
00:00:37,000 --> 00:00:40,000
This is better than just doing only XORs

10
00:00:40,000 --> 00:00:45,000
because we're moving data around instead of just XORing and changing it.

11
00:00:45,000 --> 00:00:50,000
The other thing that's really important for a cipher to be hard to cryptanalyze 

12
00:00:50,000 --> 00:00:58,000
is to have some nonlinearity, something that is very difficult to analyze

13
00:00:58,000 --> 00:01:02,000
and mixes up data in a way that is nonlinear.

14
00:01:02,000 --> 00:01:05,000
This is done basically by having lookup tables.

15
00:01:05,000 --> 00:01:10,000
So what's called an S-box is something that takes in 8 bits--

16
00:01:10,000 --> 00:01:15,000
in this case it could have different numbers going in--

17
00:01:15,000 --> 00:01:17,000
and basically has a lookup table.

18
00:01:17,000 --> 00:01:24,000
So that's going to have 256 entries mapping each set of 8 bits to some other set of 8 bits.

19
00:01:24,000 --> 00:01:27,000
And designing that lookup table is a challenge.

20
00:01:27,000 --> 00:01:31,000
We want the lookups to be as nonlinear as possible

21
00:01:31,000 --> 00:01:36,000
and make sure there are no patterns in the data in this table.

22
00:01:36,000 --> 00:01:41,000
And so the way AES works is combining shifts and S-boxes with XOR

23
00:01:41,000 --> 00:01:43,000
to scramble up the data.

24
00:01:43,000 --> 00:01:46,000
And it's going through multiple rounds,

25
00:01:46,000 --> 00:01:52,000
so we'll take the outputs of this, put them back through a series of shifts and S-boxes again,

26
00:01:52,000 --> 00:01:54,000
and keep doing that.

27
00:01:54,000 --> 00:01:57,000
The number of rounds depends on the key size.

28
00:01:57,000 --> 00:02:03,000
So for the smallest key, for the 128-bit key, which is the smallest key size for AES,

29
00:02:03,000 --> 00:02:09,000
we would do 10 rounds going through the cycle, getting the output cipher text for that block.

30
00:02:09,000 --> 00:02:14,000
So the details are definitely more complicated than this, and getting them right is very hard.

31
00:02:14,000 --> 00:02:18,000
There's lots of great resources that explain AES in detail, though.

32
00:02:18,000 --> 00:02:21,000
For our purposes we're going to think of it as a black box--

33
00:02:21,000 --> 00:02:23,000
that we can use encryption in our protocols.

34
00:02:23,000 --> 00:02:27,000
We're going to assume it has the properties that we want it to have

35
00:02:27,000 --> 00:02:31,000
and not need to look in more detail at how to actually implement that in a modern cipher.

media.name: cs387_unit1_09_q_Probability-Review-pt-1
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:03,000
Before getting onto the proof that the one-time pad is secure, 

2
00:00:03,000 --> 00:00:06,000
I want to do a brief of probability.

3
00:00:06,000 --> 00:00:09,000
If you feel very confident that you understand probability well,

4
00:00:09,000 --> 00:00:11,000
it's fine to skip this section,

5
00:00:11,000 --> 00:00:14,000
but I think for many students it will be helpful to review probability.

6
00:00:14,000 --> 00:00:16,000
For some this will be new.

7
00:00:16,000 --> 00:00:20,000
It's not necessary to have a lot of background in probability entering this class,

8
00:00:20,000 --> 00:00:23,000
but we will certainly be using it in crytography.

9
00:00:23,000 --> 00:00:26,000
To talk about probability we need to think of sets of outcomes.

10
00:00:26,000 --> 00:00:31,000
We'll use omega to represent the set of all possible outcomes.

11
00:00:31,000 --> 00:00:34,000
This is sometimes known as a probability space.

12
00:00:34,000 --> 00:00:38,000
For a simple example, if we think about flipping a coin,

13
00:00:38,000 --> 00:00:40,000
omega is the set of the outcomes we could get.

14
00:00:40,000 --> 00:00:45,000
We could get to land heads, and we'll call that H,

15
00:00:45,000 --> 00:00:49,000
or we could get it to land tails, and we'll call that T.

16
00:00:49,000 --> 00:00:52,000
If our probability space has a uniform distribution,

17
00:00:52,000 --> 00:00:56,000
that means each outcome has equal probability.

18
00:00:56,000 --> 00:01:00,000
We can write that as a probability using P as our probability function.

19
00:01:00,000 --> 00:01:05,000
P is a function that takes as its input some outcome,

20
00:01:05,000 --> 00:01:10,000
and it maps that to a real number between 0 and 1.

21
00:01:10,000 --> 00:01:13,000
Zero would mean that event never happens.

22
00:01:13,000 --> 00:01:16,000
One would mean that even always happens.

23
00:01:16,000 --> 00:01:19,000
If we assume a fair coin with a uniform distribution, 

24
00:01:19,000 --> 00:01:23,000
then the probability that we get heads is equal to 1/2,

25
00:01:23,000 --> 00:01:27,000
and the probability that we get tails is also equal to 1/2.

26
00:01:27,000 --> 00:01:30,000
That's how we think of mathematical coins.

27
00:01:30,000 --> 00:01:34,000
We hope to have mathematical coins to use in our cryptosystems.

28
00:01:34,000 --> 00:01:36,000
Real coins aren't so perfect.

29
00:01:36,000 --> 00:01:40,000
Let's assume instead that there are three possible outcomes.

30
00:01:40,000 --> 00:01:48,000
Now our probability space will be heads, tails, and edge.

31
00:01:48,000 --> 00:01:51,000
The edge outcome does not happen frequently.

32
00:01:51,000 --> 00:01:54,000
We'll make the probability distribution.

33
00:01:54,000 --> 00:02:00,000
The probability of heads is 0.4999.

34
00:02:00,000 --> 00:02:04,000
The probability of tails--we'll assume our coin is still fair,

35
00:02:04,000 --> 00:02:08,000
that the probability of tails is equal to the probability of heads,

36
00:02:08,000 --> 00:02:12,000
which is 0.4999.

37
00:02:12,000 --> 00:02:17,000
Is that enough to determine what is the probability of edge, of outcome E?

38
00:02:17,000 --> 00:02:19,000
I've given you two of the probabilities.

39
00:02:19,000 --> 00:02:24,000
Can you determine what is the probability of the third possible outcome,

40
00:02:24,000 --> 00:02:27,000
which is landing on the edge denoted by E.

media.name: cs387_unit1_09_s_Probability-Review-pt-1
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:06,000
The answer is 0.00002,

2
00:00:06,000 --> 00:00:10,000
and the reason for that is the sum of all the probabilities of all the events 

3
00:00:10,000 --> 00:00:13,000
in the probability space must be 1.

4
00:00:13,000 --> 00:00:19,000
We're certain that we get 1 of these events everytime we draw from the probability space.

5
00:00:19,000 --> 00:00:23,000
I'm not going to try flipping the coin enough times to see if I can actually make it

6
00:00:23,000 --> 00:00:24,000
land on its edge.

7
00:00:24,000 --> 00:00:28,000
The actual probability of landing on the edge is probably much lower than that.

media.name: cs387_unit1_20_s_Importance-of-Keys
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:04,000
The answer is it only helps us if we know something else about K.

2
00:00:04,000 --> 00:00:07,000
The reason for this is if K is uniformly distributed,

3
00:00:07,000 --> 00:00:10,000
and we're XORing it with these other values,

4
00:00:10,000 --> 00:00:15,000
whatever patterns that M and S have are lost when they get XORed with K.

5
00:00:15,000 --> 00:00:18,000
This is the whole point of the one-time pad that we can

6
00:00:18,000 --> 00:00:23,000
XOR a random key with a message and hide all the statistical properties in the message.

7
00:00:23,000 --> 00:00:27,000
This is not the case that it helps us by itself.

8
00:00:27,000 --> 00:00:31,000
If this was all we knew this is a potentially interesting property,

9
00:00:31,000 --> 00:00:36,000
but we need to know something more in order to use this to help break the cipher.

10
00:00:36,000 --> 00:00:38,000
Knowing something more about M would be great.

11
00:00:38,000 --> 00:00:42,000
That's the message we're trying to decrypt, but that's separate from being able to use

12
00:00:42,000 --> 00:00:44,000
this property in a useful way.

13
00:00:44,000 --> 00:00:48,000
What we really need to do is know something more about K.

media.name: cs387_unit1_23_l_Colossus
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:04,000
The first machine that was built to do this was called the Heath Robinson.

2
00:00:04,000 --> 00:00:07,000
It was named after this British cartoonist 

3
00:00:07,000 --> 00:00:11,000
who drew cartoons of crazy machines to do operations.

4
00:00:11,000 --> 00:00:14,000
This one was for peeling potatoes.

5
00:00:14,000 --> 00:00:17,000
The timeline of this is quite interesting.

6
00:00:17,000 --> 00:00:22,000
The first operator mistake--the re-transmission with abbreviations--

7
00:00:22,000 --> 00:00:25,000
happened in August 1941. That was intercepted.

8
00:00:25,000 --> 00:00:30,000
Over the next year that was enough to learn from the two intercepted messages 

9
00:00:30,000 --> 00:00:33,000
the structure of the machine and then to understand it well enough 

10
00:00:33,000 --> 00:00:37,000
to develop this technique--the double-Delta technique for finding 

11
00:00:37,000 --> 00:00:40,000
the correct configuration and to break messages.

12
00:00:40,000 --> 00:00:45,000
By December 1942 they decided to build a machine and put the resources necessary

13
00:00:45,000 --> 00:00:47,000
to design and build the machine.

14
00:00:47,000 --> 00:00:51,000
It was requested to be done by June of 1943.

15
00:00:51,000 --> 00:00:53,000
It was actually delivered 3 months early.

16
00:00:53,000 --> 00:00:57,000
By April 1943 they had the first machine delivered and operational.

17
00:00:57,000 --> 00:01:00,000
It could process messages about 2000 characters per second.

18
00:01:00,000 --> 00:01:07,000
It was able to do 7 XOR operations at 20 km per hour.

19
00:01:07,000 --> 00:01:09,000
This was not quite fast enough.

20
00:01:09,000 --> 00:01:12,000
A lot of the value in decrypting messages, especially in war time, 

21
00:01:12,000 --> 00:01:16,000
is being able to decrypt them before what the message is describing actually happen.

22
00:01:16,000 --> 00:01:18,000
They built a faster machine.

23
00:01:18,000 --> 00:01:20,000
The faster machine was called "Colossus."

24
00:01:20,000 --> 00:01:26,000
This was operational by January 1944, and the big change that made Colossus much faster

25
00:01:26,000 --> 00:01:29,000
and more useful than the Heath Robinson machines 

26
00:01:29,000 --> 00:01:33,000
was that they replaced the configurations, which were previously on a tape,

27
00:01:33,000 --> 00:01:36,000
with an electronic keytext generator.

28
00:01:36,000 --> 00:01:40,000
The logic is doing all the XORs and counting the number that are zero.

29
00:01:40,000 --> 00:01:45,000
Then it's printing out those tallies so you can go back and find the right configuration.

30
00:01:45,000 --> 00:01:48,000
The ciphertext is still on a paper tape.

31
00:01:48,000 --> 00:01:51,000
This is spinning through about 50 km an hour.

32
00:01:51,000 --> 00:01:55,000
It was a pretty impressive sight when it was operating.

33
00:01:55,000 --> 00:01:59,000
Processing 5000 characters per second.

34
00:01:59,000 --> 00:02:03,000
What made this arguably the first computer was because of electronic keytext

35
00:02:03,000 --> 00:02:05,000
this logic was a little bit programmable.

36
00:02:05,000 --> 00:02:07,000
It didn't do always exactly the same thing.

37
00:02:07,000 --> 00:02:11,000
There were ways to program it to do slightly different operations depending on 

38
00:02:11,000 --> 00:02:16,000
what the analysts through was the most useful thing to do with that intercepted cipher text.

39
00:02:16,000 --> 00:02:22,000
This is arguably the first programmable digital electronic computer.

40
00:02:22,000 --> 00:02:25,000
It wasn't fully programmable. It wasn't a general purpose computer.

41
00:02:25,000 --> 00:02:28,000
But it could be programmed to change its behavior slightly.

42
00:02:28,000 --> 00:02:31,000
You can see what this looked like during World War II.

43
00:02:31,000 --> 00:02:35,000
There are very few pictures of it. This was a very secretive operation.

44
00:02:35,000 --> 00:02:39,000
The machines were actually all destroyed after the war.

45
00:02:39,000 --> 00:02:43,000
A lot of the value in breaking a cipher is to make sure that no one else knows you've broken it.

46
00:02:43,000 --> 00:02:46,000
This is different from academic cryptography where people

47
00:02:46,000 --> 00:02:49,000
 like to publicized when they break ciphers.

48
00:02:49,000 --> 00:02:54,000
In military cryptography the whole value of breaking a cipher is your enemy keeps using it.

49
00:02:54,000 --> 00:02:58,000
You want to keep it very secretive that you've done that.

50
00:02:58,000 --> 00:03:02,000
A lot of the work on Colossus was not declassified until the mid-90s.

51
00:03:02,000 --> 00:03:06,000
Today if you visit Bletchley Park you can see a replica, a rebuilt version of Colossus.

52
00:03:06,000 --> 00:03:09,000
This is my picture of it from 2004.

53
00:03:09,000 --> 00:03:13,000
It does look very similar to the black and white picture from World War II.

54
00:03:13,000 --> 00:03:16,000
Unfortunately, they don't operate it frequently, so you won't get to see the tape 

55
00:03:16,000 --> 00:03:20,000
spinning through at 50 km an hour and all the crunching going on

56
00:03:20,000 --> 00:03:26,000
unless you're very lucky to go one of the few days a year that they might actually operate it.

57
00:03:26,000 --> 00:03:29,000
These Colossus machines had a huge impact on World War II.

58
00:03:29,000 --> 00:03:32,000
By the end of the war there were 10 of them continuously operating at Bletchley Park

59
00:03:32,000 --> 00:03:35,000
decrypting all the traffic that they could intercept.

60
00:03:35,000 --> 00:03:41,000
They decoded over 63 million letters of messages in Axis communications.

61
00:03:41,000 --> 00:03:46,000
Among the things they learned from them were the troop locations of Axis on D-Day.

62
00:03:46,000 --> 00:03:49,000
This was very helpful for planning the operation.

63
00:03:49,000 --> 00:03:51,000
Why did I tell you this story?

64
00:03:51,000 --> 00:03:56,000
First of all it is an important story in the history of both the world as well as computing,

65
00:03:56,000 --> 00:04:02,000
but this isn't meant to be a history class, although I certainly like to have historical excursions when I can.

66
00:04:02,000 --> 00:04:05,000
It's also very relevant to modern cryptanalysis.

67
00:04:05,000 --> 00:04:09,000
Modern ciphers are much better than the Lorenz cipher,

68
00:04:09,000 --> 00:04:14,000
and the main reason for that is we can use computing power to do the encryption.

69
00:04:14,000 --> 00:04:17,000
But the basic ideas are actually quite similar.

70
00:04:17,000 --> 00:04:22,000
The goal of the cipher is hide all the statistical properties that are inherent in the message,

71
00:04:22,000 --> 00:04:26,000
and they're present in the key--at least the generated key.

72
00:04:26,000 --> 00:04:29,000
The actual key we hope is perfectly random.

73
00:04:29,000 --> 00:04:34,000
Finding perfect randomness and getting it in computing is quite challenging.

74
00:04:34,000 --> 00:04:36,000
But let's assume we have a perfectly random key.

75
00:04:36,000 --> 00:04:39,000
What we learned from the perfect cipher analysis 

76
00:04:39,000 --> 00:04:42,000
is that the key must be shorter than the message.

77
00:04:42,000 --> 00:04:44,000
That means in order for the cipher to work, 

78
00:04:44,000 --> 00:04:48,000
we need to generate more key bits than we actually have.

79
00:04:48,000 --> 00:04:53,000
Even if the original key--and you can think of that in the case of Colossus 

80
00:04:53,000 --> 00:04:56,000
as the configuration of the machine that comes from some code book

81
00:04:56,000 --> 00:05:01,000
that could be perfectly randomly generated and shared between endpoints.

82
00:05:01,000 --> 00:05:04,000
That is only the starting configuration.

83
00:05:04,000 --> 00:05:09,000
There is some larger key that has to be generated to produce the cipher text.

84
00:05:09,000 --> 00:05:13,000
So both the key and the message have some statistical properties.

85
00:05:13,000 --> 00:05:16,000
The goal of cipher is to hide all those properties.

86
00:05:16,000 --> 00:05:20,000
The goal of the analyst is to find statistical properties in the cipher text

87
00:05:20,000 --> 00:05:24,000
and then to use those to break the key or the message.

88
00:05:24,000 --> 00:05:30,000
In the case of Bletchley Park breaking the Lorenz cipher, they found statistical properties.

89
00:05:30,000 --> 00:05:33,000
When you looked across channels at subsequent letters,

90
00:05:33,000 --> 00:05:36,000
there were some statistical properties that were not hidden by the cipher.

91
00:05:36,000 --> 00:05:43,000
That was because of a mechanical weakness that all the S wheels either all moved or didn't move.

92
00:05:43,000 --> 00:05:50,000
That meant that instead of having the long period with no repetition of 19 million letters

93
00:05:50,000 --> 00:05:54,000
that the users of those Lorenz machines thought it had,

94
00:05:54,000 --> 00:06:00,000
the Allies could break that down and find a pattern that was only 12,071 letters long

95
00:06:00,000 --> 00:06:04,000
with much fewer configurations to try to have a good guess of the cipher

96
00:06:04,000 --> 00:06:07,000
with many fewer guesses needed.

97
00:06:07,000 --> 00:06:10,000
In a modern cipher we think of that as a mathematical weakness.

98
00:06:10,000 --> 00:06:13,000
There's some problem is the mathematics of the cipher

99
00:06:13,000 --> 00:06:18,000
that leaves some statistical property that a cryptanalyst could exploit.

100
00:06:18,000 --> 00:06:24,000
The other relevance to modern cryptanalysis is it's really lots of hard work to do that.

101
00:06:24,000 --> 00:06:29,000
I find it quite amazing what Bletchley Park was able to do with Colossus.

102
00:06:29,000 --> 00:06:34,000
It still took 6 months of effort looking at those two messages to figure out  the key

103
00:06:34,000 --> 00:06:37,000
and interpret the key structure from that.

104
00:06:37,000 --> 00:06:44,000
That requires an awful lot of trial and error and a lot of creativity but also a lot of tedious work.

105
00:06:44,000 --> 00:06:49,000
In modern cryptanalysis we try to do as much of the tedious work as possible by computers,

106
00:06:49,000 --> 00:06:52,000
but there is still lots of hard work that goes into breaking a cipher.

107
00:06:52,000 --> 00:06:56,000
Motivation certainly helps a lot for that.

108
00:06:56,000 --> 00:06:59,000
In the case of Bletchley Park, the fear that your country was under attack

109
00:06:59,000 --> 00:07:02,000
is a pretty strong motivation.

nuggets.name: Otp Is A Perfect Cipher Pt 2

media.name: cs387_unit1_10_s_Probability-Review-pt-2
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:06,000
The answer is 0.99998. There are 2 ways to solve this.

2
00:00:06,000 --> 00:00:09,000
One is to sum these two. Not too hard to do.

3
00:00:09,000 --> 00:00:12,000
The other way to solve it is to use the complementary event property,

4
00:00:12,000 --> 00:00:15,000
which makes the math a little easier in this case.

5
00:00:15,000 --> 00:00:21,000
That property is that we know the sum of all possible events has to be 1.

6
00:00:21,000 --> 00:00:27,000
Instead of computing P valid by adding the probabilities of heads and tails,

7
00:00:27,000 --> 00:00:33,000
we can compute it by subtracking from 1 the probability of events not invalid,

8
00:00:33,000 --> 00:00:39,000
which is the probability of E, which is 0.00002.

9
00:00:39,000 --> 00:00:41,000
That would get us the same answer.

10
00:00:41,000 --> 00:00:46,000
The property that we're using to do this is the complementary even property.

11
00:00:46,000 --> 00:00:52,000
What it states is that for any event A, the probability of that event

12
00:00:52,000 --> 00:00:55,000
 and the probability of the complement of that event--

13
00:00:55,000 --> 00:00:58,000
that is of that not happening--is equal to 1.

14
00:00:58,000 --> 00:01:05,000
What not-A here means is that elements in the universe minus the elements in A.

15
00:01:05,000 --> 00:01:08,000
This is set subtraction. We can think of that like this.

16
00:01:08,000 --> 00:01:15,000
This is our universe if we have some event A all outcomes that are not part of a

17
00:01:15,000 --> 00:01:17,000
must be the complement of A.

18
00:01:17,000 --> 00:01:21,000
That's what you get by removing A from the probability set.

media.name: cs387_unit1_16_s_Perfect-Cipher-is-Impractical
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:02,000
This is a fairly tricky question.

2
00:00:02,000 --> 00:00:04,000
The first one is actually not true.

3
00:00:04,000 --> 00:00:09,000
The reason it's not true is there's no guarantee that the same cipher text 

4
00:00:09,000 --> 00:00:11,000
with different keys doesn't decrypt to the same message.

5
00:00:11,000 --> 00:00:15,000
We know that the size of M0 is no bigger than the size of K, 

6
00:00:15,000 --> 00:00:18,000
because we constructed by unioning the decryption, 

7
00:00:18,000 --> 00:00:21,000
which produces just one result over all possible keys.

8
00:00:21,000 --> 00:00:24,000
We know that it's no bigger than the number of possible keys.

9
00:00:24,000 --> 00:00:26,000
We don't know that it's actually equal to that.

10
00:00:26,000 --> 00:00:30,000
That would require another assumption about the decryption function.

11
00:00:30,000 --> 00:00:32,000
The other two properties we do know are correct.

12
00:00:32,000 --> 00:00:36,000
We know that M0 has fewer elements than M.

13
00:00:36,000 --> 00:00:38,000
This is the case because of this assumption.

14
00:00:38,000 --> 00:00:44,000
We said that the space of possible messages is greater than the space of possible keys.

15
00:00:44,000 --> 00:00:50,000
If that's the case, combined with the size of M0 being less than or equal to K,

16
00:00:50,000 --> 00:00:54,000
then we know that the size of M0 must be less than the size of M.

17
00:00:54,000 --> 00:00:57,000
The third property is also true.

18
00:00:57,000 --> 00:01:01,000
This is the key property that should give us insight why it can't be a perfect cipher.

19
00:01:01,000 --> 00:01:05,000
There exists some message in M that can't be in M0, 

20
00:01:05,000 --> 00:01:08,000
and that follows directly from this property.

21
00:01:08,000 --> 00:01:11,000
If one set is bigger than another set, there must be some element 

22
00:01:11,000 --> 00:01:14,000
in the bigger set that's not in the smaller one.

23
00:01:14,000 --> 00:01:17,000
How do we go from there to prove that it's not a perfect cipher?

24
00:01:17,000 --> 00:01:23,000
Let's remember our definition of a perfect cipher, and that was that the probability

25
00:01:23,000 --> 00:01:27,000
that the message  is some particular message given the ciphertext 

26
00:01:27,000 --> 00:01:30,000
without knowing anything other than that ciphertext

27
00:01:30,000 --> 00:01:36,000
is equal to the probability that M* was the message beforehand.

28
00:01:36,000 --> 00:01:38,000
That probably hasn't changed.

29
00:01:38,000 --> 00:01:46,000
In this case, if we have intercepted C0. This was our ciphertext for the example.

30
00:01:46,000 --> 00:01:52,000
Because of this property, we know that the probability that the message is M*

31
00:01:52,000 --> 00:01:58,000
is actually 0, because that's not in the set of possible decryptions of C0

32
00:01:58,000 --> 00:02:00,000
over all possible keys.

33
00:02:00,000 --> 00:02:03,000
But we said that M* was a message in M

34
00:02:03,000 --> 00:02:09,000
that initially had some non-zero probabilty, which is not the case that these two are equal,

35
00:02:09,000 --> 00:02:11,000
because this was greater than 0.

36
00:02:11,000 --> 00:02:14,000
We've contradicted the requirement for our perfect cipher.

37
00:02:14,000 --> 00:02:18,000
The only assumption that went into this was this one.

38
00:02:18,000 --> 00:02:22,000
We assumed that there existed a perfect cipher where the number of messages 

39
00:02:22,000 --> 00:02:24,000
is greater than the number of keys.

40
00:02:24,000 --> 00:02:26,000
We've reached a contradiction.

41
00:02:26,000 --> 00:02:31,000
This proves that there exists no perfect ciphers where the number of messages

42
00:02:31,000 --> 00:02:34,000
 is greater than the number of keys. This is bad news.

43
00:02:34,000 --> 00:02:37,000
Every cipher that's practical must be imperfect.

44
00:02:37,000 --> 00:02:42,000
This means that given some ciphertext that an attacker intercepts,

45
00:02:42,000 --> 00:02:44,000
even if the attacker knows nothing about the key, 

46
00:02:44,000 --> 00:02:47,000
they can eliminate some of the possible messages.

47
00:02:47,000 --> 00:02:52,000
This means that when people attempt to use ciphers similar to a one-time pad in practice,

48
00:02:52,000 --> 00:02:54,000
they tend to actually not work very well.

49
00:02:54,000 --> 00:02:58,000
The reason for this is that they reuse keys, because the number of messages they

50
00:02:58,000 --> 00:03:02,000
want to encrypt is greater than the number of keys they have.

51
00:03:02,000 --> 00:03:05,000
Next we'll look at an interesting historical example of this.

media.name: cs387_unit1_17_l_Lorenz-Cipher
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:04,000
I want to show you an example of the kinds of things that go wrong 

2
00:00:04,000 --> 00:00:07,000
when people attempt to use one-time pads in practice.

3
00:00:07,000 --> 00:00:12,000
This is a story that is very important to the history of computing

4
00:00:12,000 --> 00:00:14,000
as well as the history of the world.

5
00:00:14,000 --> 00:00:18,000
It's how the Allies at Bletchley Park were able to break the Lorenz cipher,

6
00:00:18,000 --> 00:00:24,000
which was a cipher used by the Nazis to communicate between the capitals of the cities of Europe.

7
00:00:24,000 --> 00:00:26,000
[Vernam's "One-Time" Pad (1919)]

8
00:00:26,000 --> 00:00:32,000
The story goes back at least to the 1919 patent that Gilbert Vernam,

9
00:00:32,000 --> 00:00:36,000
who was an engineering working at Bell Labs, got on a one-time pad system.

10
00:00:36,000 --> 00:00:38,000
It shouldn't really be called a one-time pad.

11
00:00:38,000 --> 00:00:40,000
It was a re-use pad system.

12
00:00:40,000 --> 00:00:44,000
The idea behind this is somewhat clear from the patent,

13
00:00:44,000 --> 00:00:47,000
especially if we rotate it so we can see it more clearly.

14
00:00:47,000 --> 00:00:50,000
One thing you can see is that there are five wires going into it.

15
00:00:50,000 --> 00:00:56,000
This is the output from reading a tape that encodes the message.

16
00:00:56,000 --> 00:00:59,000
The key was also on a paper tape.

17
00:00:59,000 --> 00:01:03,000
The encoding used just five bits. This was the Baudot code.

18
00:01:03,000 --> 00:01:07,000
With five bits we can encode 32 different symbols.

19
00:01:07,000 --> 00:01:11,000
That's enough for the alphabet and a few punctuation marks.

20
00:01:11,000 --> 00:01:14,000
You can see the letters were encoded.

21
00:01:14,000 --> 00:01:18,000
There's the strip down the middle that was used to align the tape.

22
00:01:18,000 --> 00:01:21,000
There are five bits to encode each letter.

23
00:01:21,000 --> 00:01:24,000
Managing paper tapes like this was difficult, 

24
00:01:24,000 --> 00:01:27,000
and the keys needed to be distributed on paper tapes.

25
00:01:27,000 --> 00:01:30,000
If the keys were constructed in a perfectly random way

26
00:01:30,000 --> 00:01:33,000
and you had enough key that you never needed to reuse it,

27
00:01:33,000 --> 00:01:38,000
this would actually be a perfect cipher. This would be a perfectly good one-time pad.

28
00:01:38,000 --> 00:01:42,000
The problem is distributing large paper tapes is pretty difficult,

29
00:01:42,000 --> 00:01:45,000
especially if you're trying to do this in war time.

30
00:01:45,000 --> 00:01:50,000
The machine that was built based around the same ideas, the Lorenz Cipher Machine,

31
00:01:50,000 --> 00:01:56,000
where instead of having a paper tape with the key you had a machine that would

32
00:01:56,000 --> 00:02:00,000
attempt to produce a good sequence of key bits.

33
00:02:00,000 --> 00:02:04,000
Of course, it's impossible for a machine to produce a perfectly random sequence.

34
00:02:04,000 --> 00:02:09,000
The structure of the machine determines properties of the sequence that's produced.

35
00:02:12,000 --> 00:02:16,000
The machine would generate a key sequence based on its configuration.

36
00:02:16,000 --> 00:02:20,000
That configuration is the initial settings of all the rotors and other parameters

37
00:02:20,000 --> 00:02:22,000
that we'll talk about soon.

38
00:02:22,000 --> 00:02:26,000
If there are two machines that start in the same configuration, 

39
00:02:26,000 --> 00:02:29,000
say one in Berlin and one in Paris,

40
00:02:29,000 --> 00:02:31,000
then they produce the same key.

41
00:02:31,000 --> 00:02:37,000
Their encryption is just the message XOR'd with the key that produces the ciphertext

42
00:02:37,000 --> 00:02:44,000
that's sent over radio wireless, received at the other end,

43
00:02:44,000 --> 00:02:47,000
which puts it into a machine starting with the same configuration.

44
00:02:47,000 --> 00:02:53,000
That means that ciphertext XOR'd with the key generated by this machine,

45
00:02:53,000 --> 00:02:57,000
starting from the same configuration will decrypt to receive the message.

46
00:02:57,000 --> 00:03:01,000
The machine was designed to produce a large number of possible sequences.

47
00:03:01,000 --> 00:03:05,000
There are a lot of complex operations, which we'll talk about a little next,

48
00:03:05,000 --> 00:03:09,000
but the key would not repeat for 10^19 letters.

49
00:03:09,000 --> 00:03:13,000
Given that this number was larger than the amount of text written by humans, 

50
00:03:13,000 --> 00:03:18,000
at least at the time, this lead the Nazis using it to believe that it provided

51
00:03:18,000 --> 00:03:20,000
the highest security they needed.

52
00:03:20,000 --> 00:03:25,000
They also were confident that because these machines operated in capitals--

53
00:03:25,000 --> 00:03:28,000
they weren't like the enigma machines, which operated in the field--

54
00:03:28,000 --> 00:03:31,000
that they never lost one of these machines.

55
00:03:31,000 --> 00:03:34,000
The Allies never actually had access to the actual machine 

56
00:03:34,000 --> 00:03:37,000
to try to figure out how it worked.

media.name: cs387_unit1_21_s_Weakness-in-Keys
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:05,000
[Evans] The answer is there are 41 different positions for the first wheel,

2
00:00:05,000 --> 00:00:10,000
and we multiply that by 31 different positions for the second K wheel.

3
00:00:10,000 --> 00:00:16,000
And so that means that every 1271 letters those wheels would repeat,

4
00:00:16,000 --> 00:00:21,000
and there are only 1271 different possible settings for the K wheels.

5
00:00:21,000 --> 00:00:24,000
Remember that based on the intercepted messages

6
00:00:24,000 --> 00:00:26,000
they had learned enough about the structure of the machine

7
00:00:26,000 --> 00:00:29,000
to know what the bits are around these wheels.

8
00:00:29,000 --> 00:00:33,000
So it's only necessary to figure out the right configuration.

9
00:00:33,000 --> 00:00:37,000
So certainly today, being able to try 1200-some possibilities

10
00:00:37,000 --> 00:00:40,000
would be trivial with a modern computer,

11
00:00:40,000 --> 00:00:43,000
and you might wonder why when they encountered this at Bletchley Park

12
00:00:43,000 --> 00:00:46,000
they didn't just go down to the store and buy a computer to solve it,

13
00:00:46,000 --> 00:00:51,000
but this was 1941. Computers didn't exist yet. They had to invent one first.

14
00:00:51,000 --> 00:00:56,000
And in fact, arguably, the first computer was invented to solve exactly this problem.

15
00:00:56,000 --> 00:01:01,000
Before we get to that, I want to make sure that we actually have enough of an advantage here

16
00:01:01,000 --> 00:01:04,000
that trying these configurations will help.

17
00:01:04,000 --> 00:01:10,000
So let's look at the probability that if we guess the right key

18
00:01:10,000 --> 00:01:13,000
we'll be able to tell that we got the right message.

media.name: cs387_unit1_18_s_Intercepting-messages
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:03,000
The answer is M XOR M'.

2
00:00:03,000 --> 00:00:06,000
The reason for this is because each cipher text 

3
00:00:06,000 --> 00:00:10,000
is the result of XORing a message with a key.

4
00:00:10,000 --> 00:00:14,000
C is equal to M XOR K.

5
00:00:14,000 --> 00:00:20,000
C' is equal to M' XOR K. Note that the K is the same in both cases.

6
00:00:20,000 --> 00:00:30,000
If we XOR C and C', that's going to be M XOR K XOR M' XOR K.

7
00:00:30,000 --> 00:00:35,000
The really useful thing that happens if you're trying to break this cipher

8
00:00:35,000 --> 00:00:37,000
is these two Ks will cancel out.

9
00:00:37,000 --> 00:00:41,000
That's why you end up with M XOR M'.

10
00:00:41,000 --> 00:00:44,000
That doesn't tell right away what the message is.

11
00:00:44,000 --> 00:00:49,000
If the messages were exactly the same M XOR M' would just be zero,

12
00:00:49,000 --> 00:00:51,000
and this wouldn't tell us anything.

13
00:00:51,000 --> 00:00:55,000
The ciphertext XORed will be zero, but they weren't exactly the same.

14
00:00:55,000 --> 00:00:59,000
When the Allies XORed these ciphertexts they didn't get all zeros.

15
00:00:59,000 --> 00:01:03,000
The reason for that was because of the abbreviations that were used in the transmission.

16
00:01:03,000 --> 00:01:09,000
An example would be if the original message has Spruchnummber, 

17
00:01:09,000 --> 00:01:18,000
meaning serial number, maybe in the retransmission it became an abbreviation Spruchnr.

18
00:01:18,000 --> 00:01:23,000
That would mean the place were the letters start to be different we start

19
00:01:23,000 --> 00:01:27,000
 to see differences between the ciphertext and the ciphertext prime.

20
00:01:27,000 --> 00:01:30,000
Unlike the key which was pretty close to random, 

21
00:01:30,000 --> 00:01:33,000
there were a lot of things you could guess about the messages.

22
00:01:33,000 --> 00:01:36,000
The Allies had a pretty good guess that the message was in German.

23
00:01:36,000 --> 00:01:40,000
The Allies could start trying. Let's say they guess the message.

24
00:01:40,000 --> 00:01:42,000
We'll guess it's M*.

25
00:01:42,000 --> 00:01:51,000
Then we could try seeing what we get when we do M* XORed with a C XORed with a C'.

26
00:01:51,000 --> 00:01:53,000
We can make some guess for the message.

27
00:01:53,000 --> 00:01:56,000
Try XORing it the intercepted ciphertext. 

28
00:01:56,000 --> 00:01:59,000
That should give us back the other message, 

29
00:01:59,000 --> 00:02:02,000
and we'll look if that looks like a possible  message.

30
00:02:02,000 --> 00:02:05,000
This is definitely a painstaking process but something that can be done.

31
00:02:05,000 --> 00:02:08,000
Once you get the two messages by this guessing process,

32
00:02:08,000 --> 00:02:10,000
then it's easy to find the key.

33
00:02:10,000 --> 00:02:13,000
Once you have the two messages through this guessing,

34
00:02:13,000 --> 00:02:17,000
you had the ciphertext intercepted. Now you know the key.

35
00:02:17,000 --> 00:02:19,000
Learning the messages might be useful. 

36
00:02:19,000 --> 00:02:22,000
By the time you've done all this work maybe it's too late for the message to be useful,

37
00:02:22,000 --> 00:02:24,000
but learning the key could be really useful.

38
00:02:24,000 --> 00:02:29,000
This was done by Col. John Tiltman who took these two intercepts

39
00:02:29,000 --> 00:02:32,000
 and determined the key that produced them.

40
00:02:32,000 --> 00:02:36,000
They had enough content here that there were 4000 letters in the intercept,

41
00:02:36,000 --> 00:02:39,000
so they had a 4000-long key.

42
00:02:39,000 --> 00:02:44,000
This key was given to Bill Tutte. This was his first assignment at Bletchley Park.

43
00:02:44,000 --> 00:02:47,000
He was to try to make sense of these key.

44
00:02:47,000 --> 00:02:50,000
After about 6 months of work, he was able to determine

45
00:02:50,000 --> 00:02:53,000
the machine structure that produced that key,

46
00:02:53,000 --> 00:02:55,000
and this is what it is.

47
00:02:55,000 --> 00:02:57,000
You have five lines going in. 

48
00:02:57,000 --> 00:03:01,000
This is the five bits in the Baudot code for encoding  each character.

49
00:03:01,000 --> 00:03:04,000
The rest of the machine is to produce the key bits.

50
00:03:04,000 --> 00:03:07,000
There is an XOR with each of these wheels. 

51
00:03:07,000 --> 00:03:11,000
These wheels will rotate with each character.

52
00:03:11,000 --> 00:03:16,000
Then there is another set of wheels that sometimes rotate and sometimes don't.

53
00:03:16,000 --> 00:03:18,000
We have these two M wheels.

54
00:03:18,000 --> 00:03:24,000
Based on the result of XORing the M wheels, either all the S wheels rotate one position

55
00:03:24,000 --> 00:03:27,000
for that character or none of them do.

56
00:03:27,000 --> 00:03:31,000
This was really the biggest weakness in Lorenz cipher--the S wheels all moved at once.

media.name: cs387_unit1_19_q_Lorenz-Cipher-Machine
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:02,000
This is the structure of the machine.

2
00:00:02,000 --> 00:00:09,000
Each letter of the message would be divided into 5 bits, and those would be XOR'd

3
00:00:09,000 --> 00:00:13,000
with the value coming from the corresponding K wheel.

4
00:00:13,000 --> 00:00:18,000
These wheels would rotate with each letter,

5
00:00:18,000 --> 00:00:21,000
and at each position they either had a 0 or a 1, 

6
00:00:21,000 --> 00:00:25,000
depending on whether there was a pin in that position or not.

7
00:00:25,000 --> 00:00:29,000
Each wheel had a different size.

8
00:00:29,000 --> 00:00:34,000
The last one had 23. The first one had 41. They were different-sized wheels.

9
00:00:34,000 --> 00:00:40,000
This would also be XOR'd with the result from the S wheels,

10
00:00:40,000 --> 00:00:42,000
which worked similarly.

11
00:00:42,000 --> 00:00:46,000
They also had positions that were either 0s or 1s around the wheels.

12
00:00:46,000 --> 00:00:49,000
The different was the K wheels turned every character.

13
00:00:49,000 --> 00:00:54,000
The S wheels only turned conditionally on the result of 2 other wheels, 

14
00:00:54,000 --> 00:00:59,000
which were the M wheels. The M1 wheel would turn every time.

15
00:00:59,000 --> 00:01:03,000
The M2 wheel would rotate depending on the value of the M1 wheel

16
00:01:03,000 --> 00:01:06,000
and depending on the XOR of those, either all the S wheels 

17
00:01:06,000 --> 00:01:09,000
would rotate by 1 or none of them would.

18
00:01:09,000 --> 00:01:14,000
Then the result of all these XORs is the cipher text.

19
00:01:14,000 --> 00:01:17,000
The is similar to the idea behind a one-time pat.

20
00:01:17,000 --> 00:01:21,000
We're XORing message with key.

21
00:01:21,000 --> 00:01:25,000
But the key is not a perfectly random sequence. It's the key generated by this machine.

22
00:01:25,000 --> 00:01:29,000
To break the cipher, once you knew the structure of the machine, that's not enough.

23
00:01:29,000 --> 00:01:31,000
You need to know the initial configuration.

24
00:01:31,000 --> 00:01:35,000
Here's the intercepted message that was intercepted over the radio.

25
00:01:35,000 --> 00:01:39,000
We can think of all the characters in the message.

26
00:01:39,000 --> 00:01:42,000
The important thing to remember about the Lorenz cipher

27
00:01:42,000 --> 00:01:48,000
is that the message encoding each character--each character is encoded into 5 bits, 

28
00:01:48,000 --> 00:01:50,000
using the Baudot code.

29
00:01:50,000 --> 00:01:54,000
The cipher text is in these same sequences where each cipher text bit 

30
00:01:54,000 --> 00:01:57,000
corresponds to one bit of that letter.

31
00:01:57,000 --> 00:02:00,000
The next one corresponds to the next bit of that letter.

32
00:02:00,000 --> 00:02:04,000
We can think of the cipher text being broken into channels

33
00:02:04,000 --> 00:02:08,000
corresponding to each part of the letter.

34
00:02:08,000 --> 00:02:14,000
That means each channel would be the sequences that repeat every 5.

35
00:02:14,000 --> 00:02:18,000
This would be part of the first letter, part of the first letter.

36
00:02:18,000 --> 00:02:20,000
This would be the second part of the first letter. 

37
00:02:20,000 --> 00:02:22,000
This would be the second part of the second letter.

38
00:02:22,000 --> 00:02:24,000
And this would be the third part of the first letter.

39
00:02:24,000 --> 00:02:29,000
This would be the third part of the second letter and so on.

40
00:02:29,000 --> 00:02:32,000
We can think of each of these as a separate channel.

41
00:02:32,000 --> 00:02:34,000
What we're going to do is use a new notation.

42
00:02:34,000 --> 00:02:40,000
We're going to subscript Z by channel and the letter for that channel.

43
00:02:40,000 --> 00:02:45,000
Zc sub i is the ith letter for channel c.

44
00:02:45,000 --> 00:02:55,000
In terms of this mapping, if we look at channel 0, that's going to be  Z0, Z5,  Z10.

45
00:02:55,000 --> 00:02:58,000
We can just break the cipher text up into channels.

46
00:02:58,000 --> 00:03:05,000
The key reason for doing this is because of this weakness that was noticed in the cipher.

47
00:03:05,000 --> 00:03:10,000
The key weakness is that all these S wheels move in turn.

48
00:03:10,000 --> 00:03:14,000
Either when we advance one position 

49
00:03:14,000 --> 00:03:18,000
they're the same for all the channels or they advance by one for all the channels.

50
00:03:18,000 --> 00:03:23,000
The value of each of these depends on the message.

51
00:03:23,000 --> 00:03:27,000
It also depends on the outputs of the K wheels,

52
00:03:27,000 --> 00:03:32,000
and it is also XOR'd without outputs of the S wheels.

53
00:03:32,000 --> 00:03:36,000
By separating it into those three pieces, we're going to be able to take advantage

54
00:03:36,000 --> 00:03:39,000
of the properties that they have.

55
00:03:39,000 --> 00:03:42,000
The key insight is that the S wheels don't always turn.

56
00:03:42,000 --> 00:03:45,000
If we look at subsequent characters, 

57
00:03:45,000 --> 00:03:49,000
there's a good chance that the S wheels have not changed.

58
00:03:49,000 --> 00:03:53,000
We're going to define ΔZ sub c, i

59
00:03:53,000 --> 00:03:58,000
as the difference between 2 subsequent characters in the cipher text for that channel.

60
00:03:58,000 --> 00:04:03,000
That's XOR'd with Zc of i plus 1.

61
00:04:03,000 --> 00:04:08,000
Now because this is for that channel, these are five-characters apart

62
00:04:08,000 --> 00:04:13,000
in the intercepted cipher text, but they're adjacent for that channel.

63
00:04:13,000 --> 00:04:17,000
What happens when we look at these values for two different channels?

64
00:04:17,000 --> 00:04:20,000
We're going to look at channel 0, 

65
00:04:20,000 --> 00:04:24,000
and we're going to XOR that with the delta value for channel 1.

66
00:04:24,000 --> 00:04:31,000
Plugging in the definitions, that's just the result of Z XORing all of these values.

67
00:04:31,000 --> 00:04:36,000
Where this becomes valuable is because we can break these down into the three parts.

68
00:04:36,000 --> 00:04:42,000
Let's break them own into parts, separating the M, the K, and the S parts

69
00:04:42,000 --> 00:04:45,000
that combined into this cipher text.

70
00:04:45,000 --> 00:04:48,000
What we get is these three things.

71
00:04:48,000 --> 00:04:56,000
For the message bits we have the XORs of all the message bits for the two channels adjacent

72
00:04:56,000 --> 00:04:59,000
and the key bits XOR'd with the message bits.

73
00:04:59,000 --> 00:05:01,000
Then we have this for the S bits as well.

74
00:05:01,000 --> 00:05:03,000
I want to ask a brief quiz here.

75
00:05:03,000 --> 00:05:13,000
For each of these combinations--this is Δm, ΔK, and ΔS.

76
00:05:13,000 --> 00:05:16,000
Supposing we could separate each of those, the question is which of these 

77
00:05:16,000 --> 00:05:18,000
inequalities are likely to be true.

78
00:05:18,000 --> 00:05:25,000
Each one we're asking whether the probability of that part being 0 is greater than 1/2.

79
00:05:25,000 --> 00:05:29,000
If it was a uniform distribution, the probability would be equal to 1/2.

80
00:05:29,000 --> 00:05:35,000
If it's not uniformly distributed, then the probability could be less than or greater than 1/2.

81
00:05:35,000 --> 00:05:39,000
I'm asking here are there any of these that we can be confident--

82
00:05:39,000 --> 00:05:44,000
or at least have a good likelihood --that the probability of the delta for the component

83
00:05:44,000 --> 00:05:46,000
is equal to zero.

84
00:05:46,000 --> 00:05:48,000
Let me remind you what the components are.

85
00:05:48,000 --> 00:05:54,000
The message is text in a language, and in this case it's in the language German.

86
00:05:54,000 --> 00:05:58,000
These are the K wheels. Each wheel rotates with every character.

87
00:05:58,000 --> 00:06:02,000
They have pins around the wheels deciding if it's a 0 or a 1.

88
00:06:02,000 --> 00:06:04,000
These are the S wheels.

89
00:06:04,000 --> 00:06:09,000
The S wheels rotate only when the output of the M wheels is a 1.

90
00:06:09,000 --> 00:06:15,000
Sometimes they don't rotate at all. Sometimes they all rotate at the same time.

media.name: cs387_unit1_21_q_Weakness-in-Keys
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:03,000
What more do we know about K?

2
00:00:03,000 --> 00:00:07,000
Here's our Lorenz machine, and we have the K wheels.

3
00:00:07,000 --> 00:00:10,000
That's what produces K, and each of these wheels might be a different size.

4
00:00:10,000 --> 00:00:15,000
The first one has 41 positions that are all set to either 0s or 1s.

5
00:00:15,000 --> 00:00:18,000
The second one has 31.

6
00:00:18,000 --> 00:00:25,000
If we're looking at ΔZ for two channels--remember what we were producing here,

7
00:00:25,000 --> 00:00:34,000
looking at the XOR of ΔZ from channel 0 XORed with ΔZ from channel 1.

8
00:00:34,000 --> 00:00:38,000
Let's focus just on these two channels--the outputs.

9
00:00:38,000 --> 00:00:41,000
The question is how many different configurations are there

10
00:00:41,000 --> 00:00:45,000
for the first two K wheels, the ones for channel 0 and channel 1.

11
00:00:45,000 --> 00:00:49,000
The numbers here are the size of those wheels.

media.name: cs387_unit1_22_q_Guessing-Keys
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:04,000
[Evans] So if you recall the separate channels, we divided the cipher 

2
00:00:04,000 --> 00:00:09,000
into the message part, the key part, and the part from the S wheels,

3
00:00:09,000 --> 00:00:12,000
and now we've concluded that if we can--

4
00:00:12,000 --> 00:00:16,000
we're going to try 1271 possible settings.

5
00:00:16,000 --> 00:00:20,000
So for 1 of those possible settings we're going to know all the key bits, 

6
00:00:20,000 --> 00:00:24,000
and that means if we guess the right setting the key will go to 0.

7
00:00:24,000 --> 00:00:27,000
So now all that's left is the other 2 parts.

8
00:00:27,000 --> 00:00:29,000
This is what we had before.

9
00:00:29,000 --> 00:00:33,000
We knew that the probability of delta M being zero was greater than a half,

10
00:00:33,000 --> 00:00:36,000
and it was actually about 0.61 for German

11
00:00:36,000 --> 00:00:39,000
because of the likelihood of message letters being repeated.

12
00:00:39,000 --> 00:00:44,000
And we knew that the probability of delta S being 0 was about 0.73,

13
00:00:44,000 --> 00:00:46,000
and that's because of the structure of the machine--

14
00:00:46,000 --> 00:00:49,000
that the S wheels don't advance every step.

15
00:00:49,000 --> 00:00:54,000
Only when the M wheels are on a 1 do the S wheels advance.

16
00:00:54,000 --> 00:01:01,000
And so now we've said if we guess right, that means the probability that the key bits are 0

17
00:01:01,000 --> 00:01:03,000
goes to 1.

18
00:01:03,000 --> 00:01:05,000
And it'll be 1 when we guess right.

19
00:01:05,000 --> 00:01:09,000
When we don't guess right it'll be ½.

20
00:01:09,000 --> 00:01:11,000
So in order to tell if we guess right, 

21
00:01:11,000 --> 00:01:17,000
we need to know that the probability of the cipher text bits when we guess right,

22
00:01:17,000 --> 00:01:21,000
the probability of the delta Zs being 0 will be different from ½.

23
00:01:21,000 --> 00:01:26,000
So the question is, what is the probability delta Z is 0 when we guess right?

24
00:01:26,000 --> 00:01:35,000
And remember that what delta Z is is the XOR of delta M, delta K, and delta S.

25
00:01:35,000 --> 00:01:38,000
So to solve this you need to think about all the different things

26
00:01:38,000 --> 00:01:42,000
that would make delta Z equal to 0 and compute their probability.

nuggets.name: Otp Is A Perfect Cipher Pt 3

media.name: cs387_unit1_26_l_Summary
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:02,000
[Evans] So we've reached the end of Unit 1.

2
00:00:02,000 --> 00:00:05,000
Let me remind you what we've covered.

3
00:00:05,000 --> 00:00:08,000
We covered symmetric cryptosystems and introduced the terminology

4
00:00:08,000 --> 00:00:12,000
and definitions we need to talk about encryption.

5
00:00:12,000 --> 00:00:16,000
In particular, we know what it means for a cryptosystem to be correct--

6
00:00:16,000 --> 00:00:20,000
that encryption and decryption are indeed inverses.

7
00:00:20,000 --> 00:00:25,000
Defining security is a much trickier thing, and we talked about ways we could define security

8
00:00:25,000 --> 00:00:27,000
for a symmetric cryptosystem.

9
00:00:27,000 --> 00:00:32,000
We introduced the one-time pad, which is a very simple but important cryptosystem,

10
00:00:32,000 --> 00:00:35,000
and it's all based on using the XOR operation.

11
00:00:35,000 --> 00:00:40,000
As long as we have a perfectly random key that's as long as the message,

12
00:00:40,000 --> 00:00:43,000
the one-time pad gives us perfect security.

13
00:00:43,000 --> 00:00:47,000
We looked at a formal way to define what a perfect cipher means

14
00:00:47,000 --> 00:00:50,000
and prove that the one-time pad has that property.

15
00:00:50,000 --> 00:00:55,000
We also saw that in order to be perfect, a cipher has to be impractical--

16
00:00:55,000 --> 00:00:59,000
that the number of keys has to exceed the number of messages,

17
00:00:59,000 --> 00:01:03,000
and that means that every cipher that's used in practice is potentially breakable.

18
00:01:03,000 --> 00:01:07,000
We saw one very interesting example of that with how the Allies at Bletchley Park

19
00:01:07,000 --> 00:01:10,000
were able to break the Lorenz cipher.

20
00:01:10,000 --> 00:01:14,000
We talked about modern symmetric ciphers which take advantage of computing power,

21
00:01:14,000 --> 00:01:18,000
following many of the same principles of the historical mechanical ciphers like Lorenz

22
00:01:18,000 --> 00:01:23,000
but using modern computing power and new ideas about how to scramble data

23
00:01:23,000 --> 00:01:28,000
to produce much more confusion and make things much more challenging for cryptanalysis

24
00:01:28,000 --> 00:01:31,000
even when attackers have access to the huge amounts of computing power 

25
00:01:31,000 --> 00:01:33,000
available today.

26
00:01:33,000 --> 00:01:36,000
I hope you enjoyed Unit 1 and have a good understanding

27
00:01:36,000 --> 00:01:40,000
of some of the theory behind symmetric ciphers and how they're constructed.

28
00:01:40,000 --> 00:01:43,000
In Unit 2 we'll look at how to actually use symmetric ciphers 

29
00:01:43,000 --> 00:01:46,000
to solve problems like sending a message securely between 2 parties

30
00:01:46,000 --> 00:01:48,000
over an insecure channel like the Internet

31
00:01:48,000 --> 00:01:51,000
and being able to use symmetric ciphers to play games online

32
00:01:51,000 --> 00:01:54,000
and to do important things like managing passwords.

33
00:01:54,000 --> 00:01:56,000
Hope to see everyone back for Unit 2.

media.name: cs387_unit1_01_l_Course-Overview
media.transcript:
﻿1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:02,000
The main things we're going to learn in this class:

2
00:00:02,000 --> 00:00:07,000
the first two units, we'll focus on symmetric cryptography and it's applications.

3
00:00:07,000 --> 00:00:11,000
Symmetric cryptography means both parties have the same key.

4
00:00:11,000 --> 00:00:13,000
So if we have two people: Alice and Bob--

5
00:00:13,000 --> 00:00:16,000
in cryptography we almost always talk about Alice and Bob--

6
00:00:16,000 --> 00:00:19,000
it's not clear why, but, they're useful people to talk about

7
00:00:19,000 --> 00:00:22,000
and they apparently have lots of secret messages to send between each other--

8
00:00:22,000 --> 00:00:26,000
and they want to send messages.

9
00:00:26,000 --> 00:00:29,000
They want to know that they couldn't be intercepted

10
00:00:29,000 --> 00:00:31,000
by some eavesdropper listening on the channel.

11
00:00:31,000 --> 00:00:36,000
In symmetric cryptography we assume that they both start knowing the same key,

12
00:00:36,000 --> 00:00:40,000
and they can use that same key for both encryption and decryption,

13
00:00:40,000 --> 00:00:43,000
we'll see more of what that means soon in this unit.

14
00:00:43,000 --> 00:00:48,000
What we'll do in units 3 and 4 is introduce asymmetric cryptography, 

15
00:00:48,000 --> 00:00:50,000
as well as some applications,

16
00:00:50,000 --> 00:00:55,000
and asymmetric cryptography is also known as public key cryptography.

17
00:00:55,000 --> 00:00:58,000
And the key difference between symmetric and asymmetric cryptography

18
00:00:58,000 --> 00:01:03,000
is that the keys used to encrypt and decrypt can be different.

19
00:01:03,000 --> 00:01:07,000
So, our message gets encrypted, it means there's some function that takes a message 

20
00:01:07,000 --> 00:01:11,000
and a key produces some encrypted message--which we call ciphertext.

21
00:01:11,000 --> 00:01:17,000
In symmetric cryptography, the decryption uses the same key.

22
00:01:17,000 --> 00:01:22,000
In asymmetric cryptography, the decryption uses a different key,

23
00:01:22,000 --> 00:01:28,000
and if the keys are different and unrelated, that means you can reveal one of the keys without revealing the other key,

24
00:01:28,000 --> 00:01:31,000
and that's the power that asymmetric encryption gives us,

25
00:01:31,000 --> 00:01:35,000
and we'll see lots of interesting ways to use that.

26
00:01:35,000 --> 00:01:37,000
And in units 5 and 6, we'll look at protocols

27
00:01:37,000 --> 00:01:42,000
 that use both symmetric and asymmetric cryptography to solve interesting problems.

28
00:01:42,000 --> 00:01:45,000
The reason most interesting protocols combine both of these 

29
00:01:45,000 --> 00:01:48,000
is because asymmetric cryptography tends to be very expensive--

30
00:01:48,000 --> 00:01:52,000
you need big keys, you need lots of mathematics--

31
00:01:52,000 --> 00:01:54,000
to do asymmetric cryptography--lots of computation. 

32
00:01:54,000 --> 00:01:57,000
Whereas symmetric cryptography can be very efficient.

33
00:01:57,000 --> 00:02:00,000
So that's why most interesting protocols--

34
00:02:00,000 --> 00:02:02,000
like the one we saw for accessing a secure website--

35
00:02:02,000 --> 00:02:05,000
involve both symmetric and asymmetric cryptography.
